title: male burglar wearing womens clothes hiding cupboard weeks
story: After Maddie, North Carolina, USA, noticed items of clothing were going missing and heard strange noises, she decided to investigate.Hearing noises coming from the wardrobe cupboard, she went to turn the knob and asked whos there  before someone answered Me. My name is Drew.She opened the door and a man was stood there wearing her clothes head to toe, including socks and shoes.The man, who has been identied as -year-old Andrew Clyde Swofford, was holding one of Maddies bags containing more of her clothing.The University of North Carolina student told local television station WHNT she could hear “rattling in my closet and I thought it was a raccoon” late last month.Maddie even thought her flat might have been haunted as she always locks her door, reporting missing clothing and “a hand print on my bathroom wall and my mirror”.She added: “Since I’ve been living here, I’ve had pieces of clothes missing like shirts and pants.”Waiting until her boyfriend arrived to help her, the student spoke calmly to Swofford and asked him to remove her clothes.She said: “I said, ‘You need to take my clothes off’, so he took my clothes off.Swofford tried on more of her clothes and admired himself in the mirror while they waited.He began telling Maddie how pretty she is and even asked for a hug at one point - but she declined the offer.Police arrived at Edge apartments, students accommodation near the university campus, at .pm on Saturday and took Swofford into custody.The clothes-thief was detained by police and held in Guilford County Jail for this incident plus other charges.He is held for a bail of ,suspected of breaking and entering, identity theft, larceny, possessing stolen goods, and failing to appear in court in connection with previous cases.The management of the accommodation building already changed the apartments locks in December after a previous unexplained break-in.Maddie and her roommate found two men they didnt know in the property.The pair are now planning to move out after the trauma of this recent incident.“Last night I did not feel safe,” Maddie said. “I slept with my roommate in her bed, I can’t stay here. My closet stinks, every time I go in there, it’s a bad vibe.”

title: half of brits are going to be short sighted after spending too much time looking at phones
story: David Allamby said half the population could have myopia by  given the amount of time children are spending with their phones – up from  per cent now.One in ten could be at risk of torn retinas or even losing their sight.Mr Allamby of Focus Clinics said Ministers had to encourage children to put down their devices and get “outside”.A survey in Ireland three years ago found the proportion of kids suffering from myopia has doubled from . per cent to . per cent in the past  years.He said: “We are sleepwalking into an epidemic.“Screen time isn’t just affecting the mental health of school children it could also be ruining their eyesight too. We face a tsunami of short-sightedness.”Academics argue that modern lestyles are putting a huge strain on the ciliary muscle – which ends up ening the eye. This in turn increases the risk of glaucoma, retinal tears and even detachment.Mr Allamby said the concern was the growing risk of Brits developing problems at a younger age. “The younger these problems start, the more serious they become at a later date.”Experts warn that modern lestyles – at-desk working and a lack of daylight – has led to a sharp rise in eyesight issues around the world.Nearly  per cent of  year-old conscripts in South Korea were found to have myopia.The Sun on Saturday revealed Chief Medical Officer Dame Sally Davies will recommend limiting kids to two-hours-a-time on their devices.Schools Minister Nick Gibb has also separately called for a ban on pupils taking smartphones into school.Digital Minister Margot James is also later today expected to confirm a bid to force social media firms by law to sign a code of conduct protecting young and vulnerable users.

title: raf tornado jets fly last time defending britain
story: They are due to be replaced by Typhoons after spending  years defending Britain.After entering service in  the jets have been used all over the world - most recently bombing Isis with missiles to push the terrorist group back through Syria and Iraq.Squadron members were welcomed back by family and friends as they landed this afternoon at RAF Marham, Norfolk.Originally named the Tornado GR the aircraft’s first use in live operations was during the Gulf War in , when  Tornado GRs were deployed from bases in Saudi Arabia and Bahrain.Later they were upgraded to the GR model, which has been used ever since over the skies of Kosovo, Afghanistan, Iraq and Syria.From now on they will only be used for training purposes over the UK, before the Typhoons officially take on the mantle in March.The new and improved RAF jets will make up the backbone of the UKs combat airfleet - joining the new fleet of F- Lightning jets.Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson said: It is with a heavy heart, but enormous pride, that we bid farewell to the Tornado from operations.This truly is the end of an era, having played a vital role in keeping Britain and its allies safe for four decades.They are flexible when flying with a mm gun for ied targets.The aircraft carry Paveway guided bombs and Brimstone and Storm Shadow missiles.They can reach top speeds of Mach . and fly to an altitude of ,ft.A Tornados wingspan is ftin and the jet is ftins in .But, after so long in service, it is only right that we now look to the future.The combination of our state-of-the art Fs and the Typhoon’s new weapon systems will keep us as a world leader in air combat for a generation.Chief of the Air Staff, Air Chief Marshal Sir Stephen Hillier said: My sincerest congratulations to the Tornado Force, ing home after more than  years of continuous commitment to defeating Daesh in Iraq and Syria - an exceptional effort from everyone, well done and thank you.As a Tornado GR pilot myself, I have seen the aircraft develop over its nearly  years of service into an outstanding combat aircraft, flown, maintained and supported by similarly outstanding air and groundcrew.The Tornado Force has been continuously deployed on operations since , serving with immense distinction in Iraq, Syria, Afghanistan, Libya and the Balkans.I will personally be very sad to see the Tornado retire, but it is time now to pass the baton to our next generation combat aircraft.The F-B Lightning is now operational and the Typhoon is now fully multi-role capable and able to take on the Tornado’s missions.We can all take immense pride in what the Tornado has achieved in defence of the nation over nearly four decades, and reflect back on the courage, commitment and achievements of everyone who has contributed to the success of this extraordinary aircraft.The RAF has already trialled its Typhoon and F- Forces’ abilities to work together.In a series of trials, the effectiveness of both s when operating alongside one another has been confirmed.With its larger payload and increased agility and range, the Typhoon will operate in concert with the stealthy F- and its next-generation sensors, delivering the UK a force ready to counter evolving threats in the global environment.

title: brexit leave eu march 29 2019 deal chequers theresa may latest
story: Theresa May is now fighting to stay on top after multiple votes eroded her vision of Brexit. Heres the latest on Britains departure from the EU.Brexit comes from merging the words Britain and exit.The term has been widely used ever since the idea of a referendum on leaving the EU was put forward.More than million people voted in the June  referendum with a turnout of . per cent. Leave won by  per cent to  per cent.People now talk about “soft” and “hard” Brexit in reference to how close the UK will be to the EU post separation.The road to triggering Article  — which saw Britain officially start the process of leaving the EU — was paved with complications for the PM, including a Supreme Court case ruling MPs needed to vote on Brexit negotiations.But it was finally triggered on March , , meaning the official departure date and move into the transition phase is due to take place on March , .The European Union is an economic and political partnership. There are currently  members states including the United Kingdom.It began as a trade group of six nations in the s.The UK first applied to join what was then the European Economic Community in  and finally became a member in .Now called the European Union, it has grown to include former Soviet bloc states and has at its heart a “single market” allowing goods and people to move freely.It has its own parliament, central bank and the euro currency used by  countries, with some members including Britain opting to keep their own money.Eurocrats have been pushing for ever closer political and financial union, which could include a European Army separate from the Nato alliance.Those in favour of leaving said Britain was being held back by EU red tape with too many rules on business.They also campaigned on the issue of sovereignty and said they wanted Britain to take back full control of its borders.Beyond the question of ceasing to be a member of the EU, what Brexit actually means in practice has been the subject of intense debate ever since.Theresa May officially triggered Article  on March ,  after which there was a two-year time limit set for negotiations to hammer out the details.The UK is therefore bound to leave the EU by March , , although there is a -month transition period.Negotiations began on June , with the two chief negotiators, Michel Barnier of the EU and former Brexit Secretary David Davis, immediately setting off to find common ground.Some of the “uncertainties” being discussed include citizens living in each others territory, border arrangements between Ireland and the UK and the amount Britain stands to pay to honour its existing EU commitments.This is a bridging agreement between the current situation – where we are members of the EU – and our long-term relationship outside the bloc.Also known as an implementation phase, it allows for the UK to keep some of the same arrangements with Brussels on trade and other matters until a new comprehensive trade agreement is sealed.In March , Britain secured a transition deal that will also allow ministers to seek trade agreements around the globe.The UK will also be free to set its own foreign policy as soon as Brexit happens, as well as negotiate and sign new trade deals anywhere in the world – to implement them in .However EU chiefs made it clear the period, which allows the UK to stay in the Single Market and Customs Union, will only come into forcethe Irish border is sorted.Former Brexit Secretary David Davis and EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier unveiled terms for the  month interim period.The UK will not be fully out of the EU until December ,  – four and a half years after the historic referendum decision.But EU leaders have suggested they could extend the transition period further.Theresa May finally struck a Brexit deal with Brussels on November ,, after days of round-the-clock talks in Brussels.But this has proved just the beginning of a long drawn-out, painful process.The opposition centred predominantly on the backstop agreement which ensures there is never a border between Northern Ireland and the Republic.The backstop will see Britain remain in the customs union for as long as necessary until an alternative way of keeping the border open is found.In a dramatic night at Westminster on January , the Prime Minister succeeded in uniting her party behind a plan to rewrite the deal to address concerns about the Irish backstop.But senior figures in Brussels, Berlin, Paris and Dublin warned that the demand only made a no-deal Brexit more likely as the clock ticks down to the UKs scheduled departure from the European Union on March .European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker described the Agreement reached after  months of negotiation last November as the best and only deal possible.And he told MEPs in the European Parliament in Brussels: The debate and votes in the House of Commons yesterday do not change that.The Withdrawal Agreement will not be renegotiated.May is set to go back to the EU and demand it ditches the hated Northern Ireland backstop in a last ditch plan to save Brexit.It came after the UK parliament backed an amendment instructing the Prime Minister to demand that Brussels replace the backstop — which aims to avoid customs checks on the island of Ireland after Brexit  — with alternative arrangements.

title: what brexit backstop plan theresa may eu irish border vote latest
story: The Prime Minister spoke at the Northern Irish border on Tuesday February  to deliver a speech regarding the border. Heres the latest on the tricky talking point.The backstop plan is essentially a safety netthere is no Brexit trade deal.It would avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.Also, it would ensure that no tarfs, quotas, rules of origin or customs processes would be applied to UK-EU trade.But it is unclearthe UK would be able to strike free trade agreements with other countries while the backstop endured.And it is feared the UK would end up being trapped in the customs union. The PM is now hoping to negotiate a way around this.On January  the Prime Minister succeeded in a parliamentary vote which united her party behind a plan to rewrite the deal to address concerns about the Irish backstop.In dramatic scenes, Tory and rebel Labour MPs voted by a margin of  to  to back a plan - the Brady amendment - which requires the PM to replace the Agreements controversial backstop with alternative arrangements to keep the Irish border open after Brexit.But senior figures in Brussels, Berlin, Paris and Dublin resisted the demand from May as the clock ticks down to the UKs departure from the European Union on March .The EUs chief Brexit negotiator has insisted the Irish border must remain a part of the Brexit deal, and said he profoundly regrets the outcome of the meaningful vote.Mr Barnier said the bloc is prepared to be “more ambitious” but insisted the Withdrawal Agreement and backstop are nailed down.Irish foreign minister Simon Coveney reiterated that Dublin remained committed to the Withdrawal Agreement in its entirety, including the backstop.The Irish Governments commitment to the entire Withdrawal Agreement is absolute - including the backstop, he said.Eurocrats announced for the first time on January  there will be checks and infrastructure at the frontierBritain quits without an agreement.A spokesman said: In a No Deal scenario in Ireland I think it is pretty obvious you will have a hard border.On February , Brexiteers told May the only way to save the deal was to abandon the backstop as they teamed up with Remainer MPs.On February , May delivered a speech about the Northern Irish border in Belfast.She said: Im here today to affirm my commitment, and that of the UK Government, to all of the people of Northern Ireland, of every background and tradition.She added that she was committed to the Good Friday Agreement and its successors.May said she was determined to work towards a solution to the Northern Irish border question that can command support from across the country, as she reiterated that there will be no hard border.She said: I know that the prospect of changing the backstop and reopening the Withdrawal Agreement creates real anxieties here in Northern Ireland and in Ireland, because it is here that the consequences of whatever is agreed will most be felt.I recognise too that the majority of voters in Northern Ireland voted to remain and that many will feel that once again decisions taken in Westminster are having a profound and in many cases unwanted impact in Northern Ireland and Ireland.So Im determined to work towards a solution that can command broader support from across the community in Northern Ireland.May added: We stand by our commitment in the Joint Report that there will be no hard border - including any physical infrastructure or related checks and controls.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what is brexit deal and what happens next
story: We explain what Theresa Mays Brexit deal is and what will happen next.The PM presented her first Brexit deal after getting the backing of the EU at the end of November.Many MPs on both sides of the aisle had slammed the Withdrawal Agreement when it was first presented in the House of Commons.Key points of that deal included:May scrapped the meaningful vote on her deal in the th hour in December. She then faced a vote of no confidence in her leadership and survived on December .The vote was postponed until after Christmas.The PMs first Brexit deal was rejected  to  votes by MPs in the House of Commons on January .She survived a second vote of no confidence in her government on January  by  votes.On January , May presented her plan B Brexit deal to MPs. Not a lot was explained about how it was changing.Key things that changed:MPs voted on Mays plan B deal on January .The UK parliament backed an amendment instructing Prime Minister to demand that Brussels replace the hated backstop — which aims to avoid customs checks on the island of Ireland after Brexit  —with alternative arrangements.A majority of MPs backed ruling out a no-deal Brexit although May has rejected this.A bid by Labour MPs for an extension of Article  failed to win votes.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit news latest backstop dup theresa may belfast
story: Speaking in Belfast, the PM vowed to back a joint bid for the  World Cup by all the countries of the British Isles.And she pledged that after Brexit, the UK will have a closer relationship with Ireland than with any other European country.Mrs May also risked angering her MPs by suggesting she might not ditch the backstop after all.In a speech aimed squarely and winning goodwill from Dublin, the PM said: Our relationship with Ireland is deeper than our relationship with any of the other . It is uniquely rooted in ties of family, history and geography.The recent past has been a moment of reflection in the UK and Ireland as we have commemorated the centenary of a series of key events in our shared history.Today those ties of family and friendship between our countries are more important than they have ever been.And I believe there is a yearning in the hearts of all the peoples of these islands for a close and trusting relationship between all of us, and an absolute horror that we should take even a single step backwards in the progress we have collectively achieved.She proposed annual meetings between the British and Irish governments after Brexit to ensure the two countries work closely together.And she added: Both the UK and the Irish Governments have already made clear that we would support the tantalising possibility of a joint UK and Ireland World Cup bid for , should our respective football associations choose to pursue this.Mrs May admitted she must face up to the fact that MPs resoundingly rejected the Irish backstop plan - which could leave the UK trapped in the European customs union.But she hinted she may not ditch the backstop altogether, saying that any Brexit deal will need an insurance policy for the future.Earlier today DUP leader Arlene Foster vowed to back the PMs dealshe succeeds in rewriting the plan for the Irish border.The DUP are crucial to Mrs Mays strategy - because she believesthey come on board and back her deal, dozens of Tory Brexiteers will follow.Today Mrs Foster told the BBC: If the backstop is dealt with in the withdrawal agreement, then despite the fact that we may have misgivings around other parts of the agreement, we will support the Prime Minister.Because we do want Brexit to happen in an orderly fashion.The unionist boss said the current backstop would have to be replaced by a dferent way of keeping the Irish border open.She promised to lobby Mrs May on the issue when they hold talks in Belfast tomorrow.She said: We will be reiterating our opposition to the current backstop. And the fact that Parliament has now backed that position means that she has a clear mandate to go back to Brussels.The current backstop is toxic to those of us living in Northern Ireland, and indeed for unionists right across the United Kingdom, because it would cause the break-up of the United Kingdom into the medium and longer term.Mrs May got a boost from Angela Merkel yesterday as the German leader called on Brussels to be flexible with Britain.And a grand committee of Tory MPs from across the Brexit ide is meeting civil servants for a second day of talks on how to find alternative arrangements which could replace the backstop.

title: corbyn second brexit referendum frankenstein
story: In a huge blow for Remainers who hope that the Labour boss will eventually throw his weight behind another Brexit vote, the uncovered video shows him slamming the bloc.And he mocked the idea of a second referendum too, saying he had a feeling theyre going to keep on voting to get the answer they want after Ireland narrowly rejected adopting the Lisbon Treaty, a video unearthed by the Red Roar revealed.In a rally in  he branded the EU as subservient to Nato and said he did not want to live in a European empire of the st century.At the event organised by the Irish Anti-War movement he said he wished Britain would have a referendum too on whether to accept the new demands from the bloc.Backbencher Mr Corbyn blasted: Under the terms of the Lisbon Treaty, Europe will become subservient to the wishes of Nato and the aims of Nato.We are creating for ourselves here one massive Frankenstein, which will damage all of us in the long run.Mr Corbyns Remain supporters think he will cave and back a fresh vote to stay in the European Union.But this video shows the Labour boss true colours - and shows that hopes he will come out in favour of a second Brexit referendum to overturn the result are incredibly slim.Even Brexiteer Nigel Farage praised the speech, saying he was a real Eurosceptic.He went on: His role will be crucial over the next few weeks.Will the real Jeremy Corbyn please stand up And SNP MP Stewart McDonald tweeted earlier: He and Farage were singing from the same song sheet, albeit from dferent ends of the political spectrum.Mr Corbyn has a long history of Euroscepticism and famously was slammed for taking a back seat in the  EU referendum.Since then hes had to walk a tightrope over Brexit to try and keep all sides of his party happy.BRITAIN should continue allow free movement in some forms after we leave, Sir Keir Starmer has said.In a signicant softening of Labours position the Shadow Brexit Secretary called for Britain to allign with the EU after we leave.He said people would be willing to accept free movement of people with some restrictions - like advertising a job locally first, or bringing family members over.Sir Keir told the BBC: If somebody is coming to do a job and it needs to be done and it has been advertised locally beforehand with nobody able to do it, then most people would say I accept that.Most people say thatyou are coming to join your family that is something I can accept. Most people would saysomebody wants to come here and study and it is genuine then of course please come and study. In fact lets celebrate that.Theresa May has vowed that free movement will end after Brexit, and has insisted that Britain will finally be able to take back control of our borders once again after we leave.Voters said that immigration was one of the major factors in voting to leave the bloc.Labour has fiercely opposed Mrs Mays Brexit deal but stopped short of endorsing a second referendum.They say they will only back another votethey cant force through a general election to seize power.A spokesperson for Mr Corbyn said today: Jeremy’s criticisms of the Lisbon Treaty over a lack of democracy in the EU, its strengthening of neoliberal economic policies and potential military expansion are well known.That’s why he campaigned both to remain and reform in the  EU referendum, so it could live up to the promise of a social Europe.He is clear that a public vote must remain an option on the table to prevent the damage of a No Deal exit from the EU.

title: no deal brexit would be fault of stubborn eurocrats playing hardball top brexiteer storms
story: Chris Grayling launched a barnstorming attack on Brussels sayingwe left without a deal they would be entirely to blame, and not us.Just hours before it was revealed that Theresa May will dash to Brussels this week for talks with the EU over her deal, he said that Britain was doing all it could to try and reach agreement.But he warned in an interview with The Daily :  If they are not willing to compromise,theyre not willing to work with us to find common ground - it will be down to themthere is no deal.And he added: We want to work with the EU to reach a deal butthey are not prepared to do that - they will have to take responsibility that we are heading towards a no-deal exit.The EU have repeatedly insisted that they wont budge on the Irish border - saying the deal is done and dusted.He insisted Mrs May would be tough in the upcoming talks, but that there would be no chance of Article  being delayed at all.Ive been in every Cabinet meeting and theres been no conversation about delaying post-March , he said.We are not delaying Article .And Mr Grayling also slapped down scaremongering reports of food shortages after we leave the EU by saying: No, Im not stockpiling.Trade would continue to flow freely after we leave no matter what happens, we insisted.So its not a case that once we leave the EU that food supplies will suddenly dry up.His comments were echoed today by ex-Brexit boss Dominic Raab.In an interview with ConservativeHome this morning he said that: It will be important for people to see thatthe EU remain stubbornly intransigent, they are the ones courting the WTO exit.People understand that we need to leave on th March. Whether they voted Leave or Remain, the one thing you hear is get this thing done and dusted.Leaving without a deal wouldnt be the end of the world, but it wouldnt be a walk in the park, he said, which is also the view of Roberto Azevedo, the Director of the World Trade Organisation.Mr Raab even hinted that Britain could be SAFER after Brexit - because well be able to refuse entry to anyone that border officials are worried about.Britain is due to leave the EU on March  no matter what happens, but the PM has promised to go back and ask for changes to the hated Northern Irish backstop.Mrs May is still clinging to her deal, but accepts that MPs dont want it in its current form.She will come up with the plan to take to Brussels later this week which involves major changes to the Northern Ireland border.

title: danny dyer right royal family flaw
story: A documentary that was as funny as it was surprising, and all the more so because the BBC did the right thing and played it absolutely straight.Genuine blue plaque television, in fact, that should never have been revisited or reformatted, not least because it would remind the Beeb that Danny’s wonderful everyman story had killed the whole WDYTYA franchise.So I’d been expecting this sucker punch, ever since its final credits rolled in .Danny Dyer’s Right Royal Family, on BBC. “A potty old adventure,” as his nibs described it, tracing Danny’s family line even further back, to Scandinavia’s King Rollo, his -times great grandfather, who I’d always assumed was a s children’s cartoon character, rather than a ninth-century Viking warrior.There were two episodes of it this time as well, which I know some of you thought were as funny as the original. Personally, I didn’t.What I hope we’re all agreed on, though, is the fact that Danny’s too busy playing Danny Dyer, the professional geezer, to be a good listener or natural TV historian.It’s an act that worked, of course, when he was wondering, “Eleanor of Aquitaine, was she a looker ” but didn’t serve him so well when presented with a longbow.“Long, innit ”The Beeb clocked this before production started, obviously, so had paired him up with dozens of head-patting historians and actors who got him to dress up as every kind of medieval t**t you can imagine. Like Mr Benn on crack, it was.Armour, codpieces, nappies, tights, doublet and hose, and a gigantic white smock, bleached with human urine, which had one grovelling “courtier” wondering: “Has all the p*** been washed out, my Lord King ”A good question.We didn’t actually get the answer, though, until part two, on Wednesday, when, after a brief detour round his ancestors, Louis IX of France, William the Conqueror and Henry II, viewers got to the nub of things, with Professor Chris Given-Wilson explaining the agonising death of Edward II: “By thrusting a hollow instrument, like the end of a trumpet, up his fundament.”“’Old on a minute,” said a rattled Danny. “He’s been stabbed  With a trumpet ”“Into his fundament.” Long pause.“Don’t tell me it’s up his a**e ”Right up it, Danny, with a red-hot poker. News which didn’t just do his “nut in”, it seemed to derail the entire documentary.They ran out of direct royal ancestors shortly afterwards as well, and the BBC adopted its stupid default setting in such circumstances. It turned Danny’s Right Royal Family into a dance and cookery show, complete with demonstrations of both, from medieval experts.It was about this time I also sussed out what was going on in the background, with all those winsome historians. title: brexit theresa stands backstop northern
story: NewsBrexit: Theresa May stands by backstop in Northern Ireland speech despite Tory rowThe Prime Minister revealed a little more of her strategy in a speech in Belfast - but risked angering Brexiteers by suggesting the backstop wont disappear completelyShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe Prime Minister revealed a little more of her strategy in a speech in Belfast  days before Brexit "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May vowed to stand the controversial Brexit backstop as she desperately tries to revive her withdrawal deal. The Prime Minister used a visit to Belfast to pledge her commitment to the “insurance policy” aimed at avoiding a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic in the event of a no-deal. She jets to Brussels on Thursday for crisis talks with EU chiefs as she tries to overhaul the agreement so she can force it through Parliament. The backstop is an insurance policy aimed at avoiding a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic in the event of a no-deal departure. It would extend EU customs rules over the UK from  January  but give us no say over them. So far Mrs May has said she is pursuing either alternative arrangements, an exit clause in the backstop, or a time limit in the backstop. EU chiefs have repeatedly said they wont ditch the backstop and wont include a time limit. Today she said: “The issue that has always been one that Parliament has raised - its been raised across all sides of the House of Commons - is the potential indefinite nature of the backstop.   “Thats the issue we look to address.” Taking questions after her -minute speech, Mrs May was also accused of having “betrayed and shafted” Northern Irish businesses over the backstop. Industry chiefs feared she was set to U-turn on pledges the measure would be in place to stop checks and infrastructure along the -mile frontier which will form the only land border between the UK and the EU. The rattled PM hit back: “There is no suggestion that we are not going to ensure that in the future there is provision – its been called an insurance policy, the backstop – that ensures thatthe future relationship is not in place by the end of the implementation period, there will be arrangements in place to ensure that we deliver no hard border. “Our commitment to that remains.” She added: “Im not proposing to persuade people to accept a deal that doesnt contain that insurance policy for the future.” But her suggestion that the backstop would not be junked then sparked anger among hard Brexiteer Tories. A source in Jacob Rees-Moggs European Research Group of MPs warned: Evenshe doesnt mean what she said, we still do.   That leaves Mrs May facing another Commons defeat in the next vote on February MPs decide shes not gone far enough. Downing Street sources later claried that all three options were still under consideration. Mrs May will skip her weekly head-to-head with Jeremy Corbyn in the Commons tomorrow as she holds talks with the DUP and Sinn Fein at Stormont. She is due to fly to Brussels for crunch showdown with EU Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker on Thursday. It will be their first face-to-face meeting since her plan suffered a crushing -vote defeat in Parliament last month. Last week, MPs agreed to back the pactshe can win changes to the backstop, The PM’s chief-of-staff Gavin Barwell travelled to Brussels yesterday earlier this week to meet European politicians and officials, paving the way for Mrs Mays visit.   She warned the Cabinet today that “the discussions with the EU will not be easy but Parliament has sent a clear message that changes to the backstop is the only way to get a deal approved”, her spokesman revealed. He added: “The PM said her objective now is to secure a legally binding way of ensuring we can’t be indefinitely trapped in the backstop.”  Work is ongoing “urgently” on three options for changing the backstop so Mrs May has something to take back to Brussels.  They include looking at “alternative arrangements” from a group of Remainer and Brexiteer Tory MPs, as well as Attorney General Geoffrey Cox’s work on a unilateral exit mechanism or time limit to the backstop.  Labour leader Mr Corbyn also revealed his own concerns about the backstop, senior ministers were told.  “This is an issue that needs to be resolved not just for our colleagues and the DUP but for MPs across the House,” her spokesman said. The DUP wants the PM to ditch the backstop altogether. But the EU has insisted there can be no withdrawal pact without one. Setting a time limit would mean that it was not an insurance policy, officials claim. British negotiators hope to secure a guarantee it will only last for a set period of time to ease fears the UK will become trapped forever in the arrangement.

title: council funding shake up help
story: NewsopinionCouncil funding shake-up will help out Tory councils instead of the most in-needShadow Communities Secretary Andrew Gwynne says Labour will vote against the Local Government Funding SettlementShareCommentsByAndrew Gwynne:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsopinionLabours Andrew Gwynne "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNo new money, no new ideas and no recognition of the dire situation facing councils - that is the reality of the Tories’ new local government settlement, which MPs are voting on today. Unless Tory ministers change tack, more elderly people will go without proper care, disabled people will be worse off, more vulnerable children will fall through the net, and our communities will become more unpleasant, unsafe and unattractive places to live. For nine years, councils have risen to the challenge of making what the Government calls “efficiency savings. But they’ve reached the end of the line, with so-called “non-essential services” being cut to the bone.  Since , over  libraries, as many as  Sure Start centres and over  youth centres have closed. This is a crisis of the Tories’ making, but they are pushing the blame onto councils, communities, carers and families. Councils are warning they are reaching a “tipping point”, but the Tories are cutting even more. The cross-party Local Government Associationhas stated that councils arefacing a funding gap of pound. billion just to keep services at the level they are in  . The crisis in social care is already having severe consequences on how we care for elderly people. It’s set to get even worse. Social care has a pound. billion funding gap next year, and . million elderly people are living without the care they need - up nearly  per cent in just two years. The Government should be investing in our most in-need areas – but they are cutting them even harder.The Tories are planning changes to the way it gives funding to councils. Instead of targeting the most deprived areas, or those with the most need, they’ll instead introduce new plans that mostly help out more affluent Tory areas.  This settlement is inadequate and unfair. Labour will vote against it to send a clear message to this Tory Government that they need to come back with proposals that give councils the funding they need. The Tories must think again before the start of the next financial year. It’s not too late.

title: mirror investigates rough sleeping britain
story: NewsThe Mirror investigates: Rough sleeping in Britain Rough sleeping has more than doubled in the last decade. The Daily Mirror is taking to the streets to find out whyShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video mirror-talks-homeless-people-cardf-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt is a scandal staring us in the face. Travel to almost any town or city in Britain and you will see people sleeping rough on the streets. And the first question you ask is “why has it gotten so bad ” The Mirror wants to know too. We want to know why, in one of the richest countries in the world, so many people living in our streets  The figures show the number of rough sleepers has more than doubled in the last ten years. But the statistics do not tell the real story.  They do not tell how someone has ended up in a hostel because of a family breakdown. Or how benefit cuts have left people without a roof over their head. Or how the lack of mental health support has left people living rough without the support they deserve. Nor do they tell the story of the veteran with post traumatic stress disorder, the young person forced to flee an abusive parent or the charity worker who has transformed someones le.  That is why the Mirror is taking to the streets. Our journalists from across Britain are going to spend time with the homeless, charities and volunteers to tell their story. We will visit churches and mosques which open their doors to the homeless, talk to those who are struggling and those who have turned their lives around and we will look at the causes behind this national crisis.  HOW YOU CAN HELP If you see someone sleeping rough you can contact Streetlink www.streetlink.org.ukin England  Wales, or the local council in Scotland, to connect that person with the homelessness services in their area. If you have immediate concerns about their welfare you should call . There are other ways you help people depending on what you feel comfortable with. * Askthere is anything they need. It could be a hot drink or food, or some spare change. * Provide blankets or warm clothing such as hats, scarfs, socks or gloves * Stop for a chat or a kind word. Homelessness can be an incredibly lonely experience.

title: mp blasts deportation flight jamaica
story: NewsMP blasts deportation flight to Jamaica in furious speech saying black lives matter lessDavid Lammy told MPs black Brits have been "enslaved, colonised and then repatriated" as  people are set to be deported on a flight to Jamaica within hoursShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video david-lammy-blasts-deportations-jamaica-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn MP has savaged the government for deporting  people to Jamaica on a charter flight thats set to leave within hours.David Lammy declared black people in Britain were once enslaved, then colonised, and then repatriated in a furious House of Commons speech today.He spoke out as a dedicated plane prepares to leave an RAF base in the early hours tomorrow bound for Jamaica. The Home Office hit back at Mr Lammy, saying all those on the flight are serious criminals - including some accused of rape and murder.But the Labour MP said  came to Britain as children, nine under the age of , and  have indefinite leave to remain.The deportations will leave  British kids with a deported parent, Mr Lammy said. And he blasted Home Secretary Sajid Javid for rushing ahead with the deportation before paying out a penny to black Britons under the Windrush scandal compensation scheme.  Before the review is even complete, why, why are you deporting people  Mr Lammy fumed. How can you be confident you’re not making the same mistakes  The MP for Tottenham added: Once enslaved, then colonised, and then repatriated. Why do you say these children should live without their parents  Why do you say [to] the families of black British people who have been killed by your department’s incompetence that this is acceptable  We are now  years on from the Macpherson review which found institutional racism in this country.  Why is it that still, in this country, black lives matter less  It comes as a chartered deportation flight to Jamaica carrying dozens of people is expected to leave the UK on Wednesday, according to reports. A number of men being held at Harmondsworth immigration centre have been told they will be flown to Jamaica on February , according to The Independent. It is believed the flight will leave from an RAF base in the early hours of Wednesday. Jamaican newspaper The Gleaner claimed that as many as  people are expected to be on the flight. Campaigners including left-wing group Momentum have organised urgent meetings in a bid to stop this plane.One dad set to be on the flight came to the UK aged  and said yesterday he will have to bring his kids up via Skype. Owen Haisley, , has been living in Britain for  years and was given the right to remain here. After spending a year in jail for domestic assault in  his status to legally remain in the UK has been ripped up. Sean Lyons, from group End Deportations, said:Deportation charter flights are a cowardly, brutal and barely legal way of forcing people out of the UK and must be stopped. The Government is ripping families apart to fill seats on a plane. But MrJavidhit back, saying the scheduled deportations were a charter flight of foreign national offenders only, and that every single one of them [was] convicted of a serious crime. He said it was a legal requirement and that Mr Lammy was asking him to break the law by not sending them to Jamaica, adding he has either changed his mind or he doesnt know what hes talking about.  The Home Secretary also took issue with the questions posed of him, saying the Labour MP does himself a huge disservice in the way that he speaks and the tone that hes used to suggest there is even an ounce of racism in this House.He added that some of those Windrush generation members who died after being deported were sent back as a result of decisions made while Mr Lammy himself was in Government under Tony Blair and Gordon Brown.MrJavidsaid the Labour MP had supported immigration restrictions and only now he chooses to speak up about some of the inadvertent effects of that. A Home Office spokesman said: It is only right that we seek to deport foreign nationals who abuse our hospitality by committing crimes in the UK. This ensures we keep the public safe. All iniduals on this charter flight are serious criminals. Mr Lammy made his comments during an urgent debate on the Home Offices handling of the Windrush scandal. The Windrush generation are British residents who arrived from Commonwealth countries before New Years Day . They are named after the Empire Windrush, the ship which brought some of the first Caribbean migrants to Britain in . Anyone who arrived in the UK from a Commonwealth country before  has a legal right to stay, unless they left the UK for more than two years. But they faced being threatened with deportation under new immigration rules despite living and working here for decades. People were ordered to prove they have the right to be in the UK to rent property, work or access services and benefits. The government failed to keep detailed records of Windrush arrivals, and landing cards were destroyed in . The Home Office set up a task force with the aim of sorting out cases within two weeks. Windrush immigrants are also being granted fee-free citizenship and a compensation scheme, the rules of which have not been set yet. Read moreyoure affected here or call a government hotline on    .  Mr Javid told MPs that after further review  people were wrongly sent back to the Caribbean, and he has written to  of them to apologise. The other three have died. Mr Lammy said: Every single one of these cases is a shocking indictment of this government’s pandering a far right racism, sham immigration targets, and a dog whistle of the right wing press. He added: We are now  months on from when this scandal broke. not a penny has been paid to any Windrush victim in a compensation scheme.

title: buses better run local councils
story: NewsBuses will be better run by local councils, say voters in a new pollBuses should be run for public benefit rather than profit, a new poll findsShareCommentsByMark Ellis:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsFirst Group bus"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailVoters have given a massive boost to letting Town Halls control local bus services, a survey has revealed. A poll of , adults found that more than eight out of tenagree that “as local authorities provide public money for the bus network, they should have more control over bus services.” The poll for Better Buses for Greater Manchester found three out of foursupported re-regulation of buses in the region. At present local authorities have no control over the fares, ticketing and the routes of around % of bus services in Greater Manchester, despite the fact that some % of bus companies revenue is public money. Some % of voters said they supported a London-style pay as you go smart card ticket which caps daily spend automatically, and is only possible with regulation. Greater Manchester is one of the first British cities to be considering re-regulating its bus network, which would give the mayor the choice to put the public in control instead of the big firms. Andy Burnham, Mayor of Greater Manchester, has to choose between parternships with bus firms or regulation, which gives local authorities control over fares, routes and timetables. Regulation will provide the ability to ‘cross-subsidise’ - using funds from busy bus routes to pay for socially necessary ones. A decision is expected later this year.  Pascale Robinson of Better Buses for Greater Manchester noted: ‘When Andy Burnham makes the decision on bus reform, we need him to listen to what people in Greater Manchester are saying clearly: we want and deserve a much better, regulated bus network. “The deregulated system has left us with an expensive, stripped-back, fragmented bus network. A regulated network will mean a bus network run for communities, not shareholders.” OneBus, a partnership of all commercial bus operators in Greater Manchester, has pledged a poundm blueprint to improve services including:investing in  new buses to improve air quality a single unied brand across all operator buses an action plan to tackle congestion hotspots and a two-year price freeze on multi-operator bus fares. Gary Nolan, chief executive of OneBus,said the mayor was evaluating an alternative franchising option, which would see taxpayers become responsible for the full cost of the bus network instead of the current system where the majority of costs are covered by bus operators. He added:”The only place in the UK where a franchising system operates is in London where bus use has fallen % in the past three years, Transport for London is facing a poundm deficit and many bus services are having to be cut.” The findings come two months after the Mirror revealed that the big five bus companies aid a staggering pound.bn in idends to shareholders over the last ten years while fares have soared and services have been axed. Meanwhile, Friends of the Earth has called for free bus travel to get people out of their cars and onto public transport to help the government reduce climate-changing greenhouse gases. Mike Childs, of Friends of the Earth, said: “Free bus travel for the under ’s at first, before widening the scheme, would make for more livable cities and cut damaging greenhouse gas emissions. “Dozens of cities across the world offer some form of free public transport. It would cost around pound billion a year, but this is a fraction of the money spent on roads. “Three times more journeys are by bus than train and they are the main means of transport for the car-less quarter of the population. What we are seeing instead is bus fares rising % over the last  years, and over , services reduced or removed since  in England and Wales.”

title: extreme lengths teenagers go perfect
story: NewsExtreme s teenagers will go to for perfect selfie has been revealedA project by Rankin has shown what teenagers really do when asked to edit their own selfies for social mediaShareCommentsByJane Lavender:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB News "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen were sharing a picture of ourselves with the world, we want to make sure thats the best it possibly can be. Taking a snap from the right angle, taking  of the same pose just to get that perfect look and getting rid of dark circles are tricks most of us have used when posting a selfie to social media . But photographer Rankins new project, Selfie Harm, shows the extreme s teenagers are prepared to go to for that perfect picture. He took close up headshots of  teenagers and then gave them the images to filter, tweak or change as they liked to create what they thought was their perfect selfie . And none of the girls pictured left their images unedited.   From changing the shape of their nose to slimming down their chins and altering lip shape and colour to altering skin tone, the list of tweaks was extensive. Many brightened or lightened their skin, added make-up, changed eye shape and even eye colour. Make-up was added digitally, cheekbones were created and faces were slimmed down. Rankin said: People are mimicking their idols, and all for social media likes.  The series of photographs forms part of Visual Diet, involving Rankin, MC Satchi and the MTArt Agency. The aim of the project is to determine how the images we are bombarded on social media are affecting mental health. Visual Diets website says: In the age of the influencer, were increasingly force-fed thousands of images every day. Hyper-retouched, sexuall gratuitous bite-sized images are served up fast and fleeting.  They often leave is feeling hollow and inadequate. These are the empty calories. The visual calories we gorge on because theyre there. Our appetite for this type of content is insatiable. It is visual sugar and were addicted. Consuming too much of this cntent seriously harms your mental health. The project has thrown up some serius issues when it comes to how young people, especially women. And the Visual Diet website offers some advice.  The website insists moderation is key. It adds: Our vision is a world where we conscously moderate our own visiaul diets by challenging the way we currently consume imagery and interact with social meida. A world where content creators and consumers consider the side effects of their uploads before they hit share. A world where success is not measured by social metrica but by well-being and positive mental health. Marine Tanguy is the founder ofMTArt Agency, the world’s first talent agency that focusses exclusively on investing in visual artists, not just art pieces.She came up with the concept of the campaignVisual Diet-the notion of replacing cheap social media gratication by instead consuming enriching visual art and has been commissioned to write a book on the campaign.

The mum-of-two says she was reading in bed when she heard the panicked cry of a woman in the street outside. The startled woman, who has reported it to police, said it was .am on Friday -  minutes after the last confirmed sighting of Libby. Libby was last seen sitting on a bench in Hull, East Yorkshire on Thursday at .pm, less than  yards away. Today her distraught parents, held hands as they released an emotional video begging her to get in touch. Mum Lisa Squire, from High Wycombe in Buckinghamshire, said: “It is breaking my heart not knowing where you are.”   The video was released as Humberside Police took to rubber dinghies for a painstaking search of nearby Barmston Drain waterway. They used an underwater camera in one of two frozen waterways, both a few minutes walk from Libby’s home. Witnesses have told how Libby was turned away from the Wellly nightclub on Thursday night for being too drunk. A pal put her in a taxi and she was dropped off outside her home a mile away. But her neighbours said she never made it through her front door and went off staggering down the street. She ended up sat on a nearby bench where she was caught on CCTV. The scream was allegedly heard just around the corner from netball player Libby’s terraced shared student house on Wellesley Avenue.   The concerned mum of two, who lives in nearby Heathcote Street near where it joins Wellesley Avenue, said: “We did hear screaming at . on Thursday night. “I was just in bed reading. We do get a lot of students who live in the road that Libby lives in who use this road as a cut through. “They go past screaming, shouting and singing. It’s not unusual. “But this made us sit up. It sounded like someone being attacked. The scream sounded like it was coming from someone who was scared. “It was someone walking quite close past our house. It was just one female scream. “It was really shrill and urgent. It made me sit up and think ‘Oh my God’.  “Then we heard other voices muttering very low, murmuring and then more screams and more male voices. “Then we heard the slamming of a door. It sounded like a wooden door or a garden gate. “It was just very odd,” added the woman, a Hull University graduate whose dad is a retired policeman. “We didn’t think about it again until the police came round knocking on everybody’s doors on Saturday,” she recalled. “We talked about it and remembered the scream and rang .”   Humberside Police have still not come around to take a statement after she reported the incident on Saturday evening. The force has been contacted for comment. Meanwhile, the hunt for the missing girl has been stepped up with officers rummaging through bins and lting drain covers in search of clues. The Hull University philosophy and religious studies student moved into her shared house with two other flat mates four months ago. Her disappearance has stunned and frightened fellow residents and students. Student Tom Wilkinson, , a pal of Libby’s flatmate Chloe Wise, said: “Everyone is scared. Everyone is still worried for her. No one feels safe when they go on a night out. “As students we got out a lot but it’s scary thinking you can’t even get a taxi back and be safe.”  Louisa Amasanti, , said: “It’s scary and surreal. No one is going anywhere alone. “Everyone has all kinds of theories but people seem to think she wandered off somewhere and fell somehow.” Her father Russell, , said in their video appeal: “Libby is our kind, thoughtful, beautul girl who is loved by so many people. As you can appreciate, this is a very dficult time for us both. “We would like to thank everyone for their help and support so far. “Your messages and kind words are a great source of strength for us both. “Please come forward with any information you may have no matter how small or irrelevant it may be, we just want Libby home.” Libby’s mother, Lisa, , added: “Libby, my darling pie. We just want to know that you are safe. “Please get in touch with us any way you can. The whole family is missing you especially me and your dad, sisters and brother. “I miss you so much. It is breaking my heart not knowing where you are. I love you more.”

story: NewsWhy list of new speed on green camera spots isnt all it seemsA list revealing the  locations in North West England was shared online - but there is one important piece of information missingShareCommentsByLaura ForsythEmilia Bona:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsA list revealing the  locations was shared online "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA list of locations for new  speed on green cameras has been circulating online - but not is all how it seems. There are  spots for the new devices in North West England, including Sefton, Knowsley, Liverpool, Wirral and St Helens. However, although the places are accurate, only a handful of the cameras are active, the Liverpool Echo reports. This means that motorists can only get caught in two of the listed locations so far. Speed on green cameras not only detect when a driver has jumped a red traffic light signal, but also record the speed of those vehicles travelling above the speed limit through a junction, regardless of the colour of the traffic light signal. A number of suitable junctions have been earmarked for the ‘speed on green’ cameras with Sefton, Merseyside, being the first area to receive them.   During the trial period, the two locations in Sefton will have active speed on green cameras - meaning drivers could get caught out at the Crosby and Maghull locations. This new type of camera records a drivers speed at traffic lights is currently being trialled on the streets of Merseyside. The temporary scheme is part of Merseyside Polices strategy to reduce the number and severity of injury collisions and to reduce the overall speed of vehicles on the regions roads. Merseyside Road Safety Partnershiphave introduced speed on green cameras at some of the countys junctions.   Each junction will be clearly signposted as a speed camera for the locations across Merseyside. story: NewsMan suicidal and sleeping on streets after Universal Credit payments cutShaun Precious, , has no money for food or a hostel after a mix-up saw job centre appointment letters sent to his late fathers home addressShareCommentsByAnna RileyNeil Murphy:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video shaun-precious-forced-sleep-streets-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A man has been left to sleep on the streets after his Universal Credit payments were cut.Shaun Precious, ,had been receiving benefits since  and has been unable to find work since his father passed away. His ordeal started after letters asking him to attend job centre appointments were sent to his late fathers address, rather than the hostel he was living in.As a result, he missed the appointments and had his benefits sanctioned, HullLive reports .He later attended a job centre meeting on Friday, February , in order to get Universal Credit money paid to him, but says he was left on hold for over an hour with a Department of Work and Pensions advisor before she hung up on him, explaining that her sht finished at .pm.   Mr Precious says he suffers from mental health issues and has been left suicidal over the mix-up. After being sanctioned through no fault of my own, Ive not been paid since December , which has left me unable to pay my rent at my hostel, and has left me starving as Ive got no money for food either, said Mr Precious. To try and fix the problem, I told the Job Centre Id only missed the meetings with them because they had sent the appointment letters to a house I dont live at, so didnt receive them, and I was told to come in to speak with one of their advisors to get my payment sorted for the next day. I went in to the Job Centre but all the woman I was assigned to did was ring the Universal Credit number and sat there on hold for over an hour trying to get through while listening to Vivaldis Four Seasons, which I could have just done myself. Then when it got to .pm, she hung up as she said she had finished her sht, and gave me another number to ring on Monday [February ], and then kicked me out to just fend for myself with no money and food, and nowhere to sleep but on the streets.  Its made me suicidal - Ive got mental issues, anxiety, depression and COPD and the streets are just no place for me to be, but Ive got absolutely no money to pay for my hostel, and nothing to eat so Im going to starve unless I can get to a food bank. Ive had to live on the streets before and its so tough and not something I wanted to have to do again - its freezing and you have to keep moving all the time and dared not fall asleep in case of getting attacked. Im just so fed up, I really am. I dont know where to turn and I cant believe that it has come to this through absolutely no fault of my own. I dont know what more to do and I just hope that my payments can get sorted soon as its really unfair. The DWP have indicated that Shaun notied them of his change of address in December and say there is a system of payments available for people who need immediate support. A spokesman said:“Universal Credit is a force for good, and is working for the vast majority of people. “Sanctions are only used in a very small percentage of cases when people fail to meet their agreed commitments infor benefits, such as a failure to attend multiple meetings with their Work Coach without good reason. “We will always contact people to resolve any issues around attendance, using the latest details they have provided us.”
