title: pub owners brutal takedown customers
story: NewsPub owners brutal takedown of customers one-star TripAdvisor reviewThe owner of the Hobgoblin in Bishopston, Bristol, delivered a scathing response to a review of the pubShareCommentsByTristan Cork:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe Hobgoblin pub in Bishopston, Bristol"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA customer who left a one-star TripAdvisor review of a pub was given short shrt by the landlord in a blistering response. The customer had allegedly claimed she was a police officer and that her human rights were violated when staff refused to give her a free round of drinks when she dropped the previous round on the floor. She later took to TripAdvisor to claim that the pubs staff had taken a disliking to her group and had an issue with happy people, Bristol Live reports.In his scathing riposte, landlord James Aylfe asked the woman, Hows the head this morning , and claimed she had been kicked out of the Hobgoblin pub in Bristol. His reply is serving as another example of bar and restaurant owners hitting back at bad reviews.   The woman, registered on TripAdvisor as ‘Chloe A’ posted on the public review website on Saturday night after allegedly being kicked out of the venue.Her review was headed ‘unreasonable’, and complained the bar staff took her for being drunk, even though she said she wasn’t. She explained how she and four friends had entered the pub but her stay did not last long. “The staff took a disliking to us the second we walked in,” she wrote. “We are a group of five who haven’t seen each other since uni. “They told us we were too drunk despite not having any alcohol before entering the establishment. This pub clearly has an issue with happy people,” she added. At least that is the best interpretation of what Chloe A wrote on TripAdvisor, Bristol Live reported.She actually tapped in: “The staff good a disliking to use the second we walked in. We are a group of  who haven’t seen us since uni. They told us we were too drunk despite not having any alcohol before entering the establishmst. This pub clearly has an issue with happy people.” Hobgoblin owner James saw the review the next day, and claims he immediately recognised who Chloe A was from the night before. He decided to respond to set the record straight, and also back up his staff, who were allegedly left upset by the experience of dealing with Chloe.   James response on TripAdvisor began inquiring after her health, before saying she might not be able to remember exactly what happened. He explained things began well - she was served a round of drinks with no problem. But then Chloe A’s time in the Hobgoblin took something of a downward turn almost immediately, because as she carried them back to the table, she spilt all the drinks after ‘stumbling away from the bar, barging into another customer’ And it was at this point, according to James, it started getting a little weird, and rather unpleasant for the staff behind the bar. She ed to the bar and ‘aggressively demanded’ replacement drinks for free, James wrote. “At this point you began threatening a member of bar staff,” he wrote, followed up by a scathing remark. “You claimed to be a police officer and that you could arrest the member of staff . “You threatened tothe following day with senior officers to pursue this further and suggested that we were infringing on your human rights,” he added. But James went on to explain the effect this behaviour had on staff and other customers. One member of staff was reduced to tears, other customers complained about her behaviour, he said. And when the assistant manager asked Chloe A to leave, she was not going to go quietly. According to James, she ‘continued to remonstrate aggressively with my assistant manager threatening all manner of consequences, demanding he hand over the full names of the staff who had refused to serve you so you could sue them for breaching your human rights’. “So the thing is Chloe,what you say is true and you really werent drunk when you arrived, then what you are asking us to accept is that these are the actions of you as a sober person,” he added, before ending by stating he was ‘completely comfortable’ with how she was treated by his staff, and suggesting that she should perhaps come to the bar with an apology. Since he posted the response on the pubs Facebook page, it has gone viral. Bristol Live has messaged Chloe A, but is yet to receive a response. James said he took the decision to share his response as a show of support for the staff involved. We dont get many one-star reviews, in fact I think hers was the just the third, so mercully we havent particularly suffered from reviews like this, he told Bristol Live . I didnt want to make a big deal about it, but I didnt feel I could just leave it unanswered. What has been really nice is that the response from customers has been almost universally positive - its been really nice to see, and nice for the staff, becauseyou get a slightly unpleasant experience it can knock your confidence in dealing with people. What was also good was that a number of people commented that they were there and that the staff did really well and acted properly, he added. James Aylfes response in full Hi Chloe, Hows the head this morning  Id be surprisedyou can actually remember your behaviour last night so, just in case its a little foggy, lets have a recap, shall we  Although you were initially served a round of drinks, after you stumbled away from the bar and barged into another customer, dropping your drinks on the floor, we began to realise that you werent *entirely* sober. This assessment was further strengthened when you ed to the bar, aggressively demanding that your spilt drinks be replaced for free. You were refused. At this point you began threatening a member of bar staff. You claimed to be a police officer and that you could arrest the member of staff . You threatened tothe following day with senior officers to pursue this further and suggested that we were infringing on your human rights. In the cold light of this morning these were rather obviously the angry ravings of someone well in their cups but as funny as it sounds now, you were extremely aggressive and intimidating at the time. A number of other customers commented that your behaviour was inappropriate, and you reduced the member of bar staff to tears. Once we had discussed what had happened, we decided that frankly it would be bestyou all moved on and we informed you that we wouldnt be serving you any further. Instead of leaving quietly with your friends you continued to remonstrate aggressively with my assistant manager threatening all manner of consequences, demanding he hand over the full names of the staff who had refused to serve you so you could sue them for breaching your human rights. So the thing is Chloe,what you say is true and you really werent drunk when you arrived, then what you are asking us to accept is that these are the actions of you as a sober person. Im really not sure that paints you in a particularly flattering light either way and I am completely comfortable with how you were dealt with last night. As for where we go from here, Ill leave that up to you. Id suggest contrition and heartfelt apology as a bare minimum requirement to you being served here againbut you are, of course, free to seek to enforce your *ahem* human rights in the courtsyou are so determined. James

title: worried shoppers find car doors
story: NewsShoppers find car doors mysteriously unlocked at busy retail parkPolice appealing for information after drivers complained vehicles targeted outside Asda in Wolstanton Retail Park, StaffordshireShareCommentsByRuby Davies:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe police were alerted to the mysterious incident"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Worried shoppers say theyve been finding their cars mysteriously unlocked at a busy retail park. Police were called in after several vehicles were reportedly unlocked at the Asda car park inWolstantonRetail Park, Newcastle-under-Lyme on Sunday.Although it was reportedly feared thieves were targeting the busy North Staffordshire area, there were no reports of any items being stolen.It is believed that a crime gang could have used a key fob jamming device to send a signal to stop motorists from locking or unlocking their doors remotely, Stoke on Trent Live reports.One driver ed from his shopping to find he could neither unlock or lock his car.   In a post on social media, he said: Just to make anyone aware who happens to be going to Asda in Wolstanton, make sure your car is locked before walking away. Ive just been there and someone is either messing about with an electronic jamming device or using one to try and steal or ransack cars. Myself and a number of other people have either come back to their cars unlocked or parked up and then not been able to lock or unlock their cars. It only seems to last a couple of minutes, but it happened at least three times while I was there. Im not suretheres anything they can do, but its been reported to the police.  Shopper Simon Hallsworth worries motorists cant do anything to protect their vehicles. The -year-old, who owns a software company, said: When you press the key fob it sends a code to the car and someone can capture that on their device and use it to unlock your car. Its worrying because at the moment theres no solution for it, so its going to get worse before it gets better. Its serious and unfortunately this technology is being used by people for the wrong purpose. At the moment theres nothing you can do until the car manufacturers find a way of making it more secure. You can open a car quite simply with the device.  Lin Lansley, from Biddulph, thinks its technology gone too far. The -year-old said: Ive heard about this happening and it is worrying. It happened to my friend where her car key was in the house and someone was able to scan it from outside and use it to unlock her car. You have to be very careful and the car manufacturers should have thought of this before making this technology. Cars are expensive and not something you take buying lightly. This technology is making it easier for people to steal cars or their contents - its not safe. Lynn Heath, , from Brown Edge, added: Its worrying, Ive heard about this happening before but you dont think its going to be local. Theres nothing you can do to stop it either. Ill try to keep an eye on my keys, but I wont be able to tellsomebody is scanning it. They need to come up with something to prevent this from happening. I prefer the old fashioned way of using the key to lock and unlock your car.  Staffordshire Police have launched an investigation into the incident. A spokesman said: Officers were called to a report of a number of cars unlocked at Asda on Wolstanton Retail Park in Newcastle just before .pm on Sunday. Anyone with information is asked to come forward. Asda confirmed it is assisting police with their inquiries. Anyone with information is asked to contact Staffordshire Police on  quoting incident number  of February .

title: i sweat 10 times much
story: NewsI sweat  times as much as a normal person and leave puddles wherever I goSophie Dwyer, , has to drink almost six litres of water every day just to stay hydratedShareCommentsByTom Ball:,  FEB NewsSophie sweats  times as much as a normal person "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailStudent Sophie Dwyer sweats  times as much as a normal person, leaves puddles wherever she goes and her clothes FREEZE because theyre so damp in winter.The -year-old student, who dubs herself the Sweat Bender, suffers from a severe form of hyperhidrosis .This is a disorder with no known cause and affects one in every  people. It means Sophies skin and clothes can be completely drenched in just a few hours. Sophie, of Houston, Texas, USA, admits it also made nights out and dating a nightmare.  She said: If Im out with friends, I make frequent trips to the bathroom to dry my armpits using a hand-dryer I sweat so much that Im pretty much always uncomfortable, but winter is by far the worst time. Its really horrible at the moment, because Im sweating just as much but the sweat runs cold. I have to dress up warmly, but I know that the sweat will start to soak through the layers, which then starts to freeze making me even colder. Theres no way I can win and it can make me really depressed sometimes.   Communication studies student Sophie, who is at Trinity University in San Antonio, Texas, Sophie, who has to drink an average of . litres of water each day to replace her moisture loss and stay hydrated.The NHS recommend . litres.But Sophie is determined to see the positive side and has turned her perspiring into a party trick, making her hands sweat on cue. She said: I call myself the Sweat Bender, after Uri Geller the Spoon Bender because I have this ability to make my hands sweat really fast just by thinking about sweating. Its like a kind of superpower, although possibly the worst superpower in the world. My friends enjoy watching it though.   But Sophie has not always found it easy to make light of her condition, which mainly affects her hands, armpits and feet. She said: I have broken my computer and my phone because of water damage, and I also really struggle to drive because the wheel slips around in my hands. I had also considered a career in medicine, but I know thats something that probably isnt an option for me - because who wants to be examined by someone with clammy hands, let alone hands dripping with sweat  Sophies parents, William, , who works for the space agency NASA, and stay-at-home mum Heidi, , realised she was stickier than her playmates. When she was two Sophies cousin, Emily, then aged four, refused to hold her hand, saying it was too gross. But, as William was also prone to sweating, they were not overly concerned, assuming she was like her dad until she reached school age, when they realised her problem was causing her embarrassment and discomfort.Single Sophie who was diagnosed when she was eight, said: I was constantly having to dry my hands on my clothes at school , to the extent where theyd always be wet. Id leave puddles on my work and kids wouldnt want to get anywhere near me. Things came to a head when Sophie was humiliated in front of her classmates by a teacher who askedshe had had an accident, on her hands as she was so wet. She said: Obviously, at that age, all the kids laughed and it was very upsetting for me, as an eight year old, to be made fun of in front of so many people. Her parents took her to see a doctor and she was diagnosed with primary hyperhidrosis, an inherited disorder that begins in childhood and normally affects only certain areas - in Sophies case, her hands, feet and armpits. She has tried ious treatments, including iontophoresis where the hands are placed in water that is connected to an electrical current, but none have been effective. Unable to find a cure for her condition, Sophie - who cannot afford Botox treatment, which can be very effective, but costs ,for each six-monthly session - found ways of adapting. She said: I began carrying sweat rags around with me all the time and would only wear very particular kind of clothes.  Youll never see me wearing a grey T-shirt and I only ever really wear white and black, which make sweat marks less obvious. Im careful to feel all of my clothes before I buy them, too. I need something that I can dry my hands on throughout the day that wont show up the moisture marks. An introverted youngster, because of her condition, she felt isolated from her peers until she joined secondary school and met a group of friends who were far more understanding and accepting of her unusual complaint.Sophie, who also has eczema on her feet because of her condition, said: When you have a disorder like mine that you cant control or stop, you can either let it make you miserable or start to own it.So I started to own it, openly telling people about hyperhidrosis and how it affects me. I think people respected that. Sometimes though, her openness about her hyperhidrosis has caused her problems.  Sophie said: I once told someone I was on a date with about it - as I always do whenever I meet someone - and he took it fine, but then kept on referencing it and making jokes about it throughout the date. I was thinking: Can we just move on  I dont like the fact that people often define me by it.Nevertheless, her hyperhidrosis is not something Sophie wants to hide from and she has created an account on the picture-sharing site Instagram to discuss openly her condition.She said: I feel like I have to embrace this, not to shy away from it and pretend like everything is fine. Im going to spend my le living with this - so I have to face up to it.

title: student thought ghost room truth
story: NewsStudent thought there was a GHOST in her room - but the truth was much worseA University of North Carolina student had clothes go missing and spotted mysterious hand prints left on her bathroom mirrorShareByChris Murphy:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB News-year-old Andrew Swofford was in the horried students closet"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA university student who thought there was a ghost in her room was disturbed when she found out the truth behind the mysterious movements. The student, of the University of North Carolina in the US, was freaked out after items in her room started disappearing and hand prints were left behind on the bathroom wall and mirror. But the young woman, known only as Maddie, discovered there was no ghost - instead, a cross-dressing man had been in her room, taking her clothes. Police, who were called to the scene in Greensboro, said the student had found a man in her clothes going through her closet. Maddie spoke with the local Fox station, but didn’t want to be fully identied.   The college junior said: “I’ve been having like pieces of clothes missing. Like shirts and pants. Items were disappearing and hand prints were left behind on the bathroom wall and mirror. But it was not until Saturday that she uncovered a mystery that she and her roommates thought was a ghost. She claimed to the channel: “I just hear rattling in my closet. It sounded like a raccoon in my closet. “I’m like who’s there  And somebody answers me. He’s like ‘oh my name is Drew.’   “I open the door and he’s in there, wearing all of my clothes. My socks. My shoes. And he has a book bag full of my clothes.” The police arrived and later confirmed the alleged cross-dressing ‘ghost’ was Andrew Swofford. The -year-old appeared in court on Monday via video conference from the Guilford County Jail. Maddie called her boyfriend, but she said she had to calmly talk to the suspect to keep him distracted until help arrived.   “He tries on my hat, she alleged. He goes in the bathroom and looks in the mirror and then is like ‘you’re really pretty, can I give you a hug ’ she recalls. “But he never touched me.” An investigation is now underway to establish how the suspect apparently got into the flat. Incredibly, it is not the first time strangers were in there. Maddie said recently she found two strange men in her lounge. She told Fox: “There were two guys in the living room.” The locks were changed after that, but somehow Swofford is alleged to have gained access. Maddie and her roommate say they’ve now had enough.   She said: “Last night I did not feel safe. I slept with my roommate in her bed. “I can’t stay here. My closet, it stinks. Every time I go in my room there’s a bad vibe. I’m just ready to leave.” Burkely Communities, the property management company, told FOX they are going through all of the details and trying to figure out how something like this happened. Previously, Swofford had been jailed in Guilford County under a , bond on  felony charges including larceny and identity theft.

story: NewsPlane makes emergency landing after pressure loss causes passengers ears to bleedThe Southwest  flight from Connecticut to Florida, America, lost pressure before passengers starting reporting severe pain in their earsShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  FEB NewsThe flight was forced to make an emergency landing in Hartford airport "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA plane was forced to make an emergency landing after a loss of cabin pressure caused a passengers ears to bleed. A passenger said: I was woken by a young woman screaming for assistance. She yelled and screamed ‘Help, help!’ because her husband felt ill. title: dundee united loan signing charlie seaman wants to return to bournemouth with medal
story: Dundee United loan signing Charlie Seaman has come to Dundee United to develop as a player and get first-team experience.And he also aims to be heading back to parent club Bournemouth this summer with a Scottish Championship medal in his pocket.In capturing the -year-old full-back from one of the surprise success stories of the English Premier League over the past few seasons, Tangerines boss Robbie Neilson stressed the deal was exactly what it said on the tin – a loan.The end of the season will see Seaman head back to the south coast and be expected to challenge for a top-team place with the Cherries.However, while his time in Scotland will be a learning experience, the former West Ham youth wants success as well.“Hopefully, coming here and learning dferent things will help me for when I go back for next season,” he said.“I can learn dferent styles here so I am really happy to be in Scotland with United.“The boys here love to play football and that’s good because it’s that way down at Bournemouth.“Every side of the game, though, on the ball, off the ball I am trying to learn, it’s what I’m here for. Defensively I am trying to be better and I want to be better offensively as well.“I came here to get experience of first-team football. I was waiting for my chance at Bournemouth but I felt I could get it here sooner, get some games for the rest of the season. Hopefully I will be more readyI get the opportunity when I go back, or wherever it may be.“There is a job to do for the team as well and our goal at Dundee United is to win this league. Yes, it would be nice to be finishing the season with a medal for that.”Seaman’s time north of the border hardly got off to the perfect start and, within hours of his arrival, he was tasting defeat as United went down to Ayr.His temporary manager was disappointed with the team performance at Somerset Park but did make a point of saying the new arrival had put in some good work.The young full-back took encouragement from that but has admitted he did not necessarily agree with Robbie’s assessment.“I was happy to make my debut last week, obviously disappointed with the loss, but it was good to get out there and experience something dferent,” he added.“I didn’t think I started the game too well but I thought I grew into it. Still, personally, I don’t think it was one of my better games by any stretch.“It was my first game at the club, my first playing a dferent style of football and my first playing in dferent weather conditions and stuff like that.“It was all a learning curve, something to take from that game into future games.“I came up Thursday night, so I only had a day here before the game but I have high expectations and I like to set high standards.“When I don’t reach them, I’m disappointed.”The aim now is to show up well as he makes his home debut as Morton visit Tannadice and United try to get back to winning ways to keep in touch with leaders Ross County.And Seaman does admit this week has given him more time to do his homework on the opposition, saying: “Before Ayr the gaffer gave me a lot of clips of Ayr to watch so I had a fair idea of what they were going to do.“I was relatively ready for the game in a tactical aspect but I did only come up on Thursday night.“For this game against Morton we have been getting information throughout the week. So I’ve an idea of what to expect and I am looking forward to playing in front of our own fans.”

title: Black Isle festival issues tongue in cheek invite to ex Oasis star
story: The announcement last week that Noel Gallagher and his High Flying Birds will take to the stage in Inverness on June  was greeted with delight by fans of the multimillion-selling star who shot to fame as the creative force behind Oasis.Less thrilled about the timing of the Bught Park gig, organised by Live in the City and boasting support from Razorlight and Neon Waltz, were the organisers of the Black Isle-based Woodzstock, scheduled to take place on the same date in an outdoor adventure park near Tore, just a few miles from Gallaghers headline-grabbing gig.Woodzstock organisers Charlotte and Dave Elliott admit they were rocked ndash and not in a good way ndash when they learned of the clash. Within hours they rallied with a defiant show must go on plan ndash to invite Gallagher to perform at their intimate venue ahead of his own show in the Highland capital.Charlotte said: "Were excited that big names like Noel Gallaghers High Flying Birds are coming to the Highlands andwe werent holding our festival on the same day we would have loved to see them play. We didnt want to miss him so were inviting Noel to come along and play a few tunes at Woodzstock before his gig in Inverness."She added: "We know it a long shot! Were asking the public to help us by posting online sharing the hashtag #GetNoeltoWoodz"Now entering its third year, Woodzstock has grown year on year with more bands, festival-goers and local businesses, including food producers, artists and performers, sound engineers and local charities, benefiting.Charlotte said: "This year promises to the best Woodzstock yet, we have some fantastic bands already booked, amazing locally sourced food and drink and activities running for the kids. An appearance from Noel would be amazing. We hope our invitation reaches him and he knows our stage will be ready for him".No one from Live in the City was available for comment on the fixture clash. Mr Gallagher could not be reached for comment.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Businesses gearing up for new adventure festival in Inverness
story: Highland Adventure Fest is expected to take place in Inverness Leisure Centre on Sunday, March .And the event is expected to feature presentations and entertainment from outdoor enthusiasts, as well as demonstrations and live music.The event is being advertised to those who have an interest in outdoor activities such as mountain biking, hiking, and kayaking among others.Festival-goers will be able to try out kit, buy new clothing and equipment, book activities and meet new people with similar interests while enjoying presentations and entertainment on the main stage.The mini festival is being planned by Inverness-based event organisers PLANIT Scotland and will be sponsored by the Glenmore Lodge in Aviemore.Katie Masheter, from PLANIT Scotland, said: ldquoWe are organising the event because the Highlands are quite often seen as a bit of an adventure playground.Miss Masheter went on to say that although they are expecting mostly local people at the event they welcome tourists to come along also, she said: ldquoVisitScotlandrsquos recent tourism conference was placing emphasis on getting the country set-up for an influx of tourists looking for adventure, so what we thought would be great is to pull together an event which brings everyone under one roof.The event is open to all.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Call to kick Inverness free parking to the kerb
story: A DRIVE to extend free parking in Inverness city centre has been described by regional Green MSP John Finnie as short-sighted and a danger to public health.City businesses would like to see the scheme which allows drivers to park for free for  minutes to be extended to half-an-hour.And they are being backed by city councillor and depute Inverness Provost Bet McAllister.The scheme was introduced last year following a campaign by the Inverness Courier and Inverness Business Improvement District and its up for review this month.Local traders said they would like to see the time limit extended so they can conduct more business.It was introduced to help improve the footfall in shops in the city centre which have been adversely affected by out-of-town retail parks.But Mr Finnie has opposed the scheme from the outset.He said the plans are ldquoshort-sighted, ill-informed and a danger to public health pointing out the city centre is already one of Scotlandrsquos air pollution hot spots.Mr Finnie said: ldquoAir pollution is the cause in thousands of deaths each year, and exacerbates many serious medical conditions.ldquoPlans to extend free parking in the city centre are ill-informed and increase the risk of air pollution related illness and death.ldquoWe need to encourage people to leave their cars at home and use buses or walk and cycle in and around Inverness. Increasing the number of cars in the city simply frustrates these efforts. More congestion means buses are less likely to run on time, for instance.He added: ldquoResearch shows that investing in cycling can signicantly improve shop occupancy and town centre spend. The Highland Council should focus its energies on putting in place quality segregated cycle routes, pedestrian prioritisation, and improving bus services, rather than inviting more and more cars into town.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: DJ marathon charity event in Inverness aims to be a money spinner
story: Several local DJs will take to the decks during the Caledonian V Cancer event this Saturday in aid of CLIC Sargent.The music starts at pm and finishes at am on Sunday, and the sound selectors will include DJs Terry Fire, Lady Beats, Andy Innis, CKaz and Richard Lewis.The event has been organised in memory of Michael Murphy who succumbed to cancer last year aged .Michaelrsquos uncle Sean , of Dalneigh, is a regular in the bar.Sean has already organised several fundraising events across Inverness, and so far he has raised more than pound for the charity.Sean said he was really grateful to the Caledonian and all the DJs for their support, adding: ldquoMichael first became unwell in  and he had two forms of leukaemia and sadly died last September.ldquoCLIC Sargent really helped us through some hard times so I became involved in the fundraising.Michael was involved in last yearrsquos Stand Up To Cancer campaign on Channel  having been filmed for the national fundraiser prior to his death.The former factory worker and McDonaldrsquos crew member lived in Forres before moving to Inverness.Mark Glendinning, general manager of the Caledonian, said: ldquoWe try to support as many local events as possible, but this one is particularly special as Sean is both a friend and regular customer.ldquoCLIC Sargent is a wonderful charity that supports cancer patients and their families during incredibly dficult times.ldquoThey were particularly helpful to Michaelrsquos we Shannon and young daughter Sophia after he passed away, so we want to help Sean raise funds for them to give something back.CLIC Sargent supports children and young people with cancer and leukaemia and the Caledonian event will be held ahead of World Cancer Day on Monday.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Highland MPs scathing after Prime Minister vows to reopen Brexit backstop negotiations
story: The - vote victory came after Speaker John Bercow selected seven amendments that iously sought to extend the date of departure, make a lsquono-dealrsquo impossible, place the Brexit process in the hands of parliament, and find an alternative to the Northern Ireland back-stop.All were defeated except the Brady Amendment ndash seeking a renegotiated backstop - and a non-binding motion calling for an economically damaging lsquono-dealrsquo to be ruled out.But Theresa May looks set to face a struggle reopening the Withdrawl Agreement negotiated with the EU after European Council president, Donald Tusk, immediately shot down the proposals, stating: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford, who is also MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber, had earlier submitted an amendment noting how the Scottish and Welsh assemblies voted against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, calling for an extension of article  ndash which would delay the UKrsquos EU departure - and for no deal to be removed as an option. It was defeated by  votes to .He warned that the development means Number  has brought the country closer to a no-deal Brexit and undermined the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland.ldquoBy throwing her weight behind an impossible demand from the hard Brexit wing of the Conservative Party the Prime Minister today demonstrated beyond doubt she is now prepared to take Scotland and the UK over the Brexit clf-edge.ldquoTheresa May could have worked across parties to protect jobs and living standards but she chose to side with the Brexit extremists in her own party.ldquoOnce again Scotland has been silenced, sidelined and shafted by Westminster, and we are paying a heavy price for a chaotic Tory government that Scotland did not vote for. And today the Tories ripped apart the Good Friday agreement, an international treaty the UK had signed up to."His SNP colleague Drew Hendry, who represents Inverness,Nairn,Badenoch and Strathspey, added: ldquoWith her Brexit deal in tatters after its record-breaking defeat in the House of Commons, Theresa Mays focus remains on appeasing her Tory colleagues, rather than on delivering a plan to protect jobs and the economy.ldquoShe knows this fudge on the Irish backstop cannot be delivered in any meaningful way, yet she continues to waste what valuable time is left. It is little wonder the EU  are so bemused by her behaviour.ldquoAs ever, it is the public who will pay the price for this shambles. The Prime Minister has made no attempt to recognise the views of the Scottish electorate, and the damage Brexit will cause to the Scottish economy.ldquoLabour has shown they are also not to be trusted, leaving us facing the prospect of being hauled out of the EU and made to endure all the damage that brings. It is clear Westminster is not working for Scotland and its time to take ownership of our own future.The Liberal Democrats voted in favour of the Labour MP Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment which was defeated by  votes to . It sought more to allow parliament more time to figure out how to break the deadlock.When this failed Liberal Democrat MP Jamie Stone, who represents Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross,argued for a Peoplersquos Vote because crashing out with no-deal would, he said, be a disaster for those in the far north.ldquoJobs, infrastructure, health care in my constituency all rely on EU citizens to fill vital roles and on EU funding," he explained.ldquoMPs who voted in favour of Bradyrsquos amendment were knowingly voting for a no deal Brexit. The EU had made it very clear to all involved that they would not reopen negotiations. These MPs are running after a fantasy and itrsquos British people who will pay the price.ldquoAll Theresa May has done is kick the can down the road and run the clock down even further. She is gambling with time we just donrsquot have.Mr Stone also sought to underline the importance of the non-binding Spelman amendment which stated the UK will not leave the EU without a deal.ldquoLabour MPs who sat on their hands have once again facilitated Theresa May and the European Research Groupin their pursuit of a no deal Brexit.ldquoA win for amendment ldquoI means the government has once again been told that there is no majority in the house for a no deal Brexit. The PM needs to take no deal off the table - as she should have done months ago - and recognise that people are not in favour of a hard Brexit which will damage our country.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: call to register interest in child adoption in north east
story: A leading north-east councillor has urged people who are considering adopting a child to register their interest.Aberdeenshire Council’s adoption team is offering assistance and support to families who are interested in joining the programme.The local authority offers a full in-house permanence planning service for children to allow them to move in with families who have worked with adoption services and have been properly prepared for the process.Bosses at the service say this allows them to tailor support accordingly for both the families and the children in their care.Concurrency planning is offered where the children are under two years old, along with post-adoption care.In its most recent Care Inspectorate report, the service received the top rating for its staffing and quality of care and support.Councillor Gillian Owen, chairwoman of the council’s education and children’s services committee, said: “There are children in Aberdeenshire who desperately need families, soyou are considering adoption, I would encourage you to register for the preparation to adopt course to seeit is for you.”“The team are friendly, supportive and have a wealth of knowledge about the process of adoption.“They take great care in matching children with families as well as using techniques and strategies to help children and their new family bond together in a loving and caring environment.”

title: new food initiative could be served up across aberdeen
story: Bosses of an innovative new food initiative hope it can eventually expand across Aberdeen.The Woodside Pantry, due to open to the public next Monday, offers a new way for people in financial trouble to get food.Led by Community Food Initiatives North East , the pantry offers an innovative subscription service to members and is the first of its kind to exist in Scotland.An annual subscription fee of £ and a £. supplement before every visit entitles members to take  items of their choice, including up to three exclusive items.Dave Simmers, the CEO of CFINE, hopes that –the scheme is successful – it can be rolled out to other regeneration areas across the city.Plans have also been hatched to create a pantry and clothes shop at the charity’s Poynenook Road headquarters.Mr Simmers said: “The Woodside Pantry is the first in Scotland, but we’re speaking with the Scottish Government and with Aberdeen City Council about investment to firstly establish a pantry at our premises, along with a clothes store.“Then what we want to do is to establish a network of community pantries across the city’s regeneration areas.”Mr Simmers said: “One of the most unfortunate parts of the past seven years has been the rise in foodbank use.“Our foodbank is up to more than  parcels daily, Monday to Friday. There’s a general agreement that it’s not very dignied.“The pantry is a way for people to access affordable food, but they’re paying for it.”Claire Whyte is a support worker at Fersands and Fountain Community Project, and also a partner in the pantry with CFINE.She said: “CFINE approached us with the concept, which is designed to replace foodbanks. We had a shop and a foodbank, and no one was really using the shop, but the foodbank was inundated.“It was the same at CFINE when they approached us, so I think it was just perfect timing.”Claire agreed with Mr Simmers that the pantry model is one that could spread beyond the boundaries of Woodside.She said: “CFINE want to roll several of these out across the city, so we’re really just the guinea pigs here.“They’re hoping to reach into every regeneration area, or at least most of them, in the city over the next few years.“This is just the start of something that is going to be much bigger in Aberdeen and hopefully across the country once we get this set up.”

title: north east lifesavers honoured for service
story: Six volunteers have been honoured for  years of lesaving.A special Royal National Leboat Institute dinner was held at Banff Springs Hotel to mark the achievements of the Macduff Leboat Station crew members.John Ingram and John West retired after more than  years service each, while Derek Mair, Colin Wood, Chassey Findlay and David Park picked up long service medals.Mr Ingram retired from his role as Deputy Launching Authority– which saw him involved in the day-to-day management of the station – at the end of .Mr West joined the RNLI in  and was DLA until  when he became the honorary secretary for Macduff RNLI, a position he held until  after which he ed to being one of the stations DLAs.Both men were presented with tide clocks.The long service medals were handed out by leboat operation manager Roy Morrison.Mr Mair has had  years of service, after joining in .The next to receive the award, Mr Wood, joined in  and has worked as both shore and boat crew over his career.Mr Findlay, who was given a -year medal, became helmsman only three years after joining, a position he has held to this day.He said: “With over  years of volunteering service between us it is testament not only to the character of the volunteers but also the RNLI, as the charity that saves lives at sea, they make sure that we are supported, equipped and trained so when the worst happens at sea we are ready and able to help people in need.”The last recipient of the award was Mr Park, who was unable to attend the dinner, but was given a -year long service medal by area lesaving manager Henry Weaver.Mr Morrison said: “They are all volunteers and are ordinary people who do extraordinary things and without them the RNLI wouldn’t be the service it is today.“Collectively these three guys have dedicated  years’ service to the RNLI, for that we are truly grateful and appreciate all that they have done during their time at Macduff. We wish them all the best in their retirement and look forward to seeing them from time to time at the station.”

title: north east man to perform on one of britains largest cruise ships
story: A performer from the north-east has set sail on his latest adventure – as a singer on one of Britain’s largest cruise ships.Robbie Mackenzie, from Newmachar, will spend  months cruising the Canary Islands and Mediterranean as part of the onboard entertainment team on Marella Dream.The -year-old fought off hundreds of other talented singers in a nationwide audition process and will be joined by  other talented young performers from across Europe.The group were recruited by Yorkshire-based firm Peel Talent and have finally set sail following a gruelling -week rehearsal process.The former Dyce Academy pupil, who also studied at the Glasgow Academy of Musical Theatre, will take part in  dferent shows over the course of his time at sea.Each will be performed twice nightly on a two-week rotation.Robbie said: “This will be my first cruise with Marella, so I am incredibly excited.“The whole process has been really enjoyable, from the auditions at Pineapple Dance Studios in London to the last  weeks where myself and the team have lived and worked together   to get all the shows ready.“It’s been very demanding as I perform several solos, including Shake a Tail Feather in the Blues Brothers-inspired show – but I have enjoyed every minute and can’t wait to become part of the Marella team.”Marella Dream is operated by Marella Cruises, which is the third-largest fleet of cruise ships in the UK.The firm is famous for its West End-style onboard shows and has proved a springboard for many talented young performers to launch their careers, including Joseph Fletcher and Cleopatra Joseph, who have gone on to perform in high-profile shows for stage and screen.

title: north east supermarkets launch valentines day competition to find longest married couple
story: A supermarket giant is on the hunt for the north-east’s longest-married couple in time for Valentine’s Day.Asda stores in the area, including at the Bridge of Dee and Portlethen, are looking to offer a prize as part of a competition for those in long-term relationships.Couples are in with the chance to win a selection of Valentine’s Day treats to mark the occasion, including luxury chocolates and a bouquet.Martin Green, general store manager at Asda Bridge of Dee, said: “We know we’ve lots of romantics around the area and what better way to celebrate Valentine’s Day than by inviting them to the store to share the love. We’re appealing for couples from across the area to put themselves forward.”Abbie Whitelaw, community champion at Asda Portlethen, said: “There are couples in our store who we’ve seen shopping together for years, and we’ve no doubt that some of these regular customers could be in with a chance of winning.”Entries to the competition will be accepted up to pm on Sunday, and should include contact details and a photocopy of the marriage or civil partnership certicate.Members of the public have been urged to email asdascotland@havas

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayr united 2 inverness 3
story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights. It’s a dficult one to take to get beat.They’re a big strong team and at times we didn’t cope with that.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr NewsAyr United FC

title: bob shields national trust who
story: NewsBob Shields: National Trust owe an apology over asking people for donations to restore Burns CottageShareByGary Fanning:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsBurns Cottage needs restoration"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI’m trying to imagine the back-slapping and glad-handing at the National Trust For Scotland’s Hermiston Quay headquarters when someone came up with a spfing ‘Save Burns Cottage’ wheeze. “Let’s send out a begging letter to all those with Burns Cottage closest to their hearts – the people of Ayr . . .” “Wonderful idea!” “We could arrange for it to land on their doorsteps on Burns birthday – January  . . .” “That’s genius!” “Throw in some pictures of cracked walls and the dodgy thatched roof . . . “ “Fantastic!” “Use phrases like “before it’s too late” – or “damaged beyond repair” . . . “It’s heartbreaking!” “That’s Burns Cottage sorted then! Gin and tonic anyone ” “Large ones all round!” To be serious though – I still can’t decide what made me angrier. The crass begging bowl letter – hoping to cash in on the biggest Burns day of the year  Or the fact that Burns Cottage has been allowed to fall into such a state that phrases like “damaged beyond repair” are even necessary  If we’re talking man’s insensitivity to man here – then last Friday’s NTS letter takes the bannock! Its contents have upset dozens of people I know – and judging by the reaction on social media, hundreds more that I don’t know. Nicky Cotter wrote: “NTS . . . put your hands in your pockets and get it fixed. If you can spend pound, on a wooden tree house at Culzean Castle – you can stump up pound, to fix one of the most historically and culturally signicant buildings in Scotland”. Spot on, sir. The NTS letter tells us that “time and Scotland’s wet winters have taken their toll”. Yes – that’ll be the  winters since Burns father William Burness built the cottage on . And during that period, it’s been thatched more times than Wayne Rooney’s balding napper. If the current thatch “has signicant tears and has worn away”, you have to askthe last thatching work was in some way inferior - orthe cottage needed re-thatched several years ago and the work was never undertaken  You then start wondering how the auld clay biggin’ managed to survive the  wet Scottish winters between the cottage being built and the National Trust for Scotland’s formation back in   The answer is fairly obvious. Back then – people looked after it! And you only have to look at the recent row over the deteriorating Burns Monument to start wonderingthe NTS is the right custodian of our Burns heritage  Burns Cottage is everything Mr Cotter said earlier . .. and more. It’s the most important building in Ayrshire – by a lang Scots mile. Every nook, cranny - and twig of its roof - should be the subject of a fingertip, annual inspection. And whatever work is required – at whatever cost – should be sanctioned immediately. In fact, I imagine that’s what ‘most people’ thought was already happening. But then we had last Friday’s mail . . . when ‘most people’ discovered to their horror that the north-west gable is starting to pull away from the rest of the cottage! If admission fees don’t cover the cost of Burns Cottage – then put them up! The last figures I have show , visitors in . Charging them an extra p would have reached the pound, required – with enough left over to putty the windows as well. So, I’m sorry, NTS. But this was the wrong letter . . . to the wrong people . . . on the wrong day. You owe a lot of honest men and a lot of bonnie lassies an apology!Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr

title: driver who sped 70mph through
story: NewsDriver who sped at mph through streets of Troon is jailed for  monthsMark Kirkby almost killed his passenger when he finally crashed into a wall following the high speed chase.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  FEB NewsMark Kirkby was jailed for the reckless driving"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who drove like a maniac through the streets of Troon has been jailed for  months, writes Edwin Lawrence. Mark Kirkby, , almost killed passenger Kerrie Anne Monaghan when he finally crashed into a wall. Miss Monaghan was in Ayr Sherf Court on crutches to hear the sentence on her partner, who she is standing by. The court heard Kirkby did not even have a driving licence and Sherf John Montgomery banned him from holding one for four years. Depute fiscal Lindsay Bain told the court police spotted a silver Volvo being driven erratically from Barassie Street into Portland Street. The police car’s blue lights went on and Kirkby initially slowed down before increasing speed. He was hitting mph in Templehill before heading into Harbour Road. And Kirkby’s car was said to have taken off as he drove across a mini roundabout into Port Ranald Drive. He hit mph in North Shore Road, eventually crashing into a wall at the Beach Road Kilmarnock Road junction in Barassie. During the whole episode, which began around .am on October  last year, Kirkby drove dangerously through junctions and swerved round corners.  When the crash occurred the car’s airbags were deployed but this did not prevent Ms Monaghan’s horric injuries. She had to be cut out of the car by firefighters and suffered numerous fractures to her face, head, body and limbs. “Kerrie Anne Monaghan is very lucky to be alive,” said fiscal Ms Bain. The court also heard of offences committed by Kirkbywhose address was given as Barlinnie Prison, on June . This time he was in a grey Ford Mondeo around .am when police spotted the car stationary on the A near the Pennyburn Roundabout. Kirkby was unsteady on his feet and slurring his speech, although a breath test proved negative. A a blood test found substances identied as cocaine and benzocaine. Defence lawyer Hugh Duncan said Kirkby’s relationship with Ms Monaghan was still ongoing. “He accepts full responsibility,” said the lawyer. “He comes across as remorseful to the injuries his partner suffered and to potential harm he could have done to others.” Mr Duncan said Kirkby had been remanded in custody since October , had undergone a detox programme, and had come to a realisation of his mental health issues. Sherf John Montgomery told Kirkby: “You drove dangerously at high speed for an extended period. I see no option but a custodial sentence.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnHMP BarlinnieVolvoAyrCourtsJusticeTroon

title: elliots prestwick evolve rebrand vics
story: NewsElliots in Prestwick to "evolve" with rebrand as Vics  The VineBosses at Buzzworks say the bar and restaurant must "evolve" as part of its transformation.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB NewsBuzzworks managing director, Kenny Blair, is promising bold changes at Elliots "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of Ayrshire’s biggest hospitality venues has closed for a “complete transformation”. Elliots in Prestwick will be given a new brand and feature live sport and entertainment seven days a week. The bar and restaurant shut its doors on Sunday, with bosses planning to reopen at Easter as Vic’s  The Vine. Buzzworks, who have operated Elliots as their flagship in the town, say the rebrand will be split into two halves. Managing director Kenny Blair said: “It’s essential to evolve within the hospitality industry and look at innovative ways to create new and exciting concepts for our customers. “Our work to reincarnate Elliots is part of our wider growth strategy, both benefiting the local community and Scotland’s hospitality industry.” Vic’s  The Vine will feature a -cover restaurant called The Vine serving food from breakfast until late. The bar will be called Vic’s and will be a “modern take on a traditional bar”, featuring sport and entertainment. Weekend opening hours will remain at .am.  Designer Jim Hamilton is leading the project, which will include a new glass roof in part of the bar. A new kitchen boasting a churrasco BBQ pit is also planned. Bosses say Vic’s will be the first venue in Ayrshire to serve fresh, unpasteurised tank beer straight from the brewery. Kenny added: “We’ve seen an appetite in the industry for more cool and modern pubs and, similarly to our T-Bar in Ayr, Vic’s will be a traditional bar with a twist. “This will both suit the local market and sit alongside our excellent new restaurant offering in Prestwick. “Our vision is to create the best day-to-night venue in Scotland and we are confident Vic’s  The Vine will match those expectations.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrPrestwickAyr News

title: pet heaven crematorium opens doors
story: NewsPet Heaven crematorium opens doors in Ayr as businessman offers new serviceBusinessman Forbes Robertson is bidding to provide a new service for animal owners in South Ayrshire.ShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB NewsForbes at the helm of his newest business "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen an adored pet pops off its mortal coil you used to allow the vet to handle it, or a space was found in the back garden. Now the proposition has got a whole lot dferent. Pet Heaven, a crematorium for family animals, has just opened in Ayr. And businessman Forbes Robertson believes it is the answer for many families who want to give their four legged - or two-legged in the case of birds - friends a splendid send-off. No expense has been spared in an -month project at the former commercial garage site in West Sanquhar Road. Area MP Bill Grant performed the official opening ceremony last week. The lavishly decorated gilded interior includes a parlour where families can pay their last respects. Entrepreneur Forbes, who has business interests throughout the area, revealed up to  people can attend the pet funeral services . Mourners can watch as their pet recedes behind the final curtain at the close of the service, similar to what would happen in a human ceremony at Masonhill. As yet Pet Heaven cannot handle horses, but the biggest of dogs to cats, hamsters and birds. There is a tea and coffee service as well as any choice of music desired and a book of remembrance in the reception area.  Much of the interior decoration has been gathered by Forbes, a keen antique hunter and auction room collector. The company will offer a collection service as well as provide a selection of remembrance urns for ashes. It seems no expense is spared by some dog lovers in the UK and recently a couple spent pound on a full funeral including a horse drawn glass hearse. Forbes said: “People sometimes care more about their animals than humans. “A farmer who contacted me askedhis dog goes before him, the animal would be cremated here and I will store the ashes. “He told me his lawyer would be in touch as he wanted buried with his dog. “Pets are loyal, they don’t steal from you and are there first thing in the morning and last thing at night.” MP Bill Grant said Pet Heaven was a signicant investment for the area. He said: “I am sure this will be welcomed by pet owners from all over the southwest, pet owners who have lost their best friend. “To have a dignied departure for that pet who has been their friend - in some cases for  years - is a great service. “The set-up Mr Robertson has here is wonderful and I think he can be proud of it. “That last journey for pets will be full of dignity and respect from Pet Heaven and its staff. “Indeed my family had a wee dog Blackie for  years and I don’t mind admitting, then a senior fire officer, that I cried unashamedly for an hour at the loss of our companion”.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrPetsSanquharAyr News

title: cold-weather-makes-it-harder-for-us-to-get-out-of-bed-says-survey
story: Chilly winter mornings lead usto spend an extra  hoursin bed over the colder months - just from hitting the snooze button.Weneed an extra  minutes in bed each morning during winter before wefeel brave enough to face the cold, according to a new survey.Of those surveyed who are currently employed,  per cent thought they were more likely to be late for work in the winter months because they found it harder to get up in the morning.Andof that %,the average worker will be late for work seven times in the course of an average winter because they overslept.One in five have been so cosy they have pulled a sickie to have a duvet day instead.A spokesperson for Andrews Heat for Hire, which commissioned the study, said: ldquoDarker, colder mornings can make waking up in winter months more challenging than any other time of the year.ldquoAnd while an additional quarter of an hour snoozing each day doesnrsquot seem like a big sacrice, over the course of the winter we lose an entire day to those few extra minutes in bed.Regionally, Scots are the quickest to get up and face the day when the weather turns, spending  minutes extra in bed, while those living in Yorkshire are fondest of their covers, resisting the cold until theyrsquove had  extra minutes dozing.One in two Brits find it harder to get themselves out of bed in winter more than any other time of year, and a third think they are more likely to hit the snooze button when the mornings are dark and cold.And seven in  said a few more minutes with their duvet is too tempting when the weather outside looks chilly.To read the full results of the study, visitandrews-sykes blog.Three in five of those questioned make it tougher to leave their beds by taking actions to make their set-up as warm and comfortable as possible.Of these,  per cent will buy a thicker duvet when the weather begins to turn, and  per cent will put an extra blanket on the bed to keep the cold away.More than seven in  even have the foresight to set their heating to come on before they wake up so their home is warm when they wake, clicking on  minutes before they stir.One in five of those surveyed have been so attached to their bedspread they have been late for a meet-up with friends or loved ones - and will also cancel six gatherings entirely over a typical winter because its too cold.Nearly one in two Brits are unable to shake their hibernation instincts when the temperature plummets and spend more time in bed during the winter than any other time of year.Three in  find themselves going to bed earlier as the evenings draw in sooner, and one in eight set their morning alarms later than they usually would to grab a few extra minutes before feeling the chill.A spokesperson for Andrews Heat for Hire, who comissioned the survey, said: ldquoWith a cold snap predicted over the coming weeks,duvets are only going to become even more inviting. At least Brits are taking measures to reduce the struggle, by planning ahead and setting their heating to come on before their alarm.

title: confused-commuters-have-world-turned-upside-down-in-galashiels
story: COMMUTERS had their world turned upside down in Galashiels last week.For four or five days confused bus passengers at the Transport Interchange struggled to read the real-time arrival and departure screens - as they were all upside down.And the confusion continued right through to the start of this week.Selkirk pensioner Jaye Riddell told us: "It was a bit dficult to make out when buses were due - I cant read upside down writing."There was one child lying on the ground trying to read the times out to to his grandparents."Thankfully the train timetables were the right way up."Scottish Borders Council is responsible for the large interactive timetable screens at the Transport Interchange.And their IT people managed to fix the upside-down problem on Monday.A spokesman told us: "The issue with the information boards has been resolved and everything is the right way up now."

title: ben-magowan-announced-as-melrosian-elect-for-2019
story: TAKING up the reins as this years Melrosian-Elect is a -year-old childrens nurse from Gattonside.Ben Magowan was announced in the role at the annual Ex-Melrosians Association Burns Supper on Saturday night.The former pupil of Melrose Primary, St Marys School and Earlston High said: "I was very nervous on the evening but its such an honour to be asked to be the Melrosian-Elect."It was an exciting evening and I had my family there to support me."Im already looking forward to the summer and have started learning about the other towns festivals."The Burns Supper was a sell-out and guests were entertained by Sandy Telfer who proposed the toast to the Immortal Memory followed by Harry Fletchers Toast to the Lassies and Annabel Crawfords reply. title: devon-based-hotel-group-buys-cringletie-house
story: AN award-winning country house hotel in Peeblesshire is about to change hands.Cringletie House Hotel, which was named AA Hotel of the Year for Scotland in , was placed on the market just over a year ago with an asking price of pound. million.The -bespoke-bedroom baronial retreat has been bought by Devon-based Cross Hotels Limited.And the official hand over will take place on February .Johanna and Jacob van Houdt have owned Cringletie for the past  years.Jacob told us: ldquoWe acquired Cringletie in a derelict state in  and invested time and money creating a destination for holidays in the Scottish Borders."Cringletie is now ready for a new phase of development and further growth."We are delighted that the Crossrsquos are bringing new energy and ideas to this magnicent project.Cringletie is set in  acres of land near Eddleston.As well as offering guests luxury room accommodation there is also a two-bedroom letting cottage in the grounds as well as staff accommodation.The hotel is also home to a -year-old walled garden and Dutch styled parterre garden.And there is also a large area of land available for further development.Bill Cross, Director of Cross Hotels, said: ldquoThe van Houdtrsquos have created a very stylish hotel at Cringletie House."We look forward to enhancing the operation and in due course extending the facilities."

title: mens-shed-goes-all-pc-with-eildon-donation
story: LOCAL social landlord Eildon Housing are setting a recycling example by donating old PCs and office furniture to a Mens Shed group.The Selkirk-based housing association handed over four computers as well as cupboards to Kelso Mens Shed last week.Eildons Chief Executive Nile Istephan told us: "As part of the on-going modernisation of our business processes, we had some surplus furniture and computers that we wanted to put to good use."In line with one of our corporate values of being connected to the communities that we work within, it is great that we can donate our surplus equipment to such a worthy cause.ldquoThe Menrsquos Shed movement provides the community with a very valuable service, by offering recreational facilities to help advance the social needs, health and well-being of people of all ages and backgrounds living in Kelso and surrounding areas."Along with a number of other organisations we have also provided financial support for a Menrsquos Shed Development worker to maximise the potential for this inspirational idea across our region.Kelso Mens Shed already has over  members.The organisation meets every Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday between am and pm.Bob Stather from Kelso Menrsquos Shed added: ldquoWe are extremely grateful for this very kind donation which will be of enormous benefit to our new Shedders."Getting on-line will be a priority for some of our new members, and this will be made possible thanks to Eildonrsquos generous donation.
