title: Caithness Moray link is completed
story: THE Caithness-Moray electricity transmission link will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come, the man who led the project has said.Dave Gardner, director of transmission for Scottish and Southern Electricity NetworksTransmission, was speaking after it was announced that the construction, commissioning and energisation of the link had been completed at a cost of around pound million.He hailed it as a signicant achievement for SSEN and everyone involved."Caithness-Moray has been a highly complex project, requiring very high standards of project design, development, construction and commissioning," Mr Gardner said. "It has been delivered by a team of committed and skilled people, working closely with contractors and other stakeholders."It will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come."Now an operational asset, we will closely monitor the link and associated infrastructure to ensure its continued success as an integral part of the GB transmission system."We would like to thank all those who contributed to the success of the project, from our own teams of engineers and support staff, our supply chain and the local communities who have played host to our project teams over recent years."Caithness-Moray is the largest single investment ever undertaken by the SSE Group and is described as the most signicant investment in the north of Scotland electricity transmission system since the s.The link uses HVDCtechnology to transmit power through a km subsea cable beneath the Moray Firth seabed between new converter stations at Spittaland Blackhillock . Constructed over a period of four years, the project also involved work at eight electricity substation sites.Completed on time and within the allowance approved by the regulator Ofgem, the Caithness-Moray link provides up to MW of capacity to transmit power from the increasing sources of renewable energy from across the far north.The link has already enabled turbines from Beatrice offshore wind farmand Dorenell onshore wind farmto connect to the national grid with a further MW of onshore generation in Caithness and Ross-shire due to connect in the coming months.The completion of the link and other electricity transmission projects is expected to help take the Regulatory Asset Valueof SSEN Transmission to around pound. billion at March , .Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Did aliens visit Wick
story: While millions of people around the country were cheering on the fireworks that brought in the new year, a Wick man and his family say they were witnessing a light show they never expected.Charlie Williamsonsays he had just popped out the back door of his house at Leishman Avenue after the bells sounded at midnight, only to spot a strange light overhead.He beckoned his we Tanya and their three children onto the doorstep from where he says they observed the strange object with flashing lights that ldquohovered in one place for over three hours.Speaking to the Courier, he says he wasnrsquot the only one to witness the eerie phenomenon.ldquoA local woman and some people south of the town also witnessed the strange sight.After Charlie posted a video of his sighting online, media ndash including the Scottish Sun ndash ran stories on his UFO experience.Many readers, however, wrote off the object as merely a drone.Charlie says he is ldquo per cent sure that is not the case.ldquoIt was way too big, he says. ldquoI donrsquot know much about drones other than the size of them but a few people have messaged me saying they wonrsquot fly for a solid three hours. It was windy that night too and a lot of people who fly drones have told me it wouldrsquove been too windy that night to fly one.Keith Banks, an amateur meteorologist who writes a monthly weather column for the John OrsquoGroat Journal, says mphgusts were blowing during the period the UFO was witnessed.ldquoIn my view the very blustery conditions would have effectively precluded a drone from flying, he said.Dedicated drone flyers agree, including Barry Scollay from Wick who says he has been flying the unmanned aerial vehicles for a decade.ldquoNo way a drone would have flown in those winds ndash thatrsquos a certain fact, said Mr Scollay, who has a Facebook page called Highland Aerial Views which has over , followersldquoIt would have to have been able to maintain its location in high winds. Irsquove flown very large drones in mph wind but that was the limit, he says.ldquoYou can [even] hear the wind howling in his video.Whatrsquos more, he says that software in operation at the nearby Wick airport would not allow such a drone to take off.Small hobby drones ldquocanrsquot fly within the airportrsquos no-fly zone.Charlie reckons the UFO was about ft above his head, larger than a car and made no sound.Although he took photos and video on his smartphone he admits that the quality was not the best.ldquoIt was like seeing a car at the bottom of your street, it was that clear. Itrsquos just not as clear with the phone.The object disappeared not long after a police van appeared at around am.ldquoI couldnrsquot get to sleep and kept going to the window and the door to see it but it was gone, he says.Since posting the video online he has had numerous calls from self-professed ldquoUFO investigators.Therersquos been so many of them, he says hersquos now ldquovery waryof callers who ask ldquotoo many questions.ldquoItrsquos like being interviewed by the FBI, he said. ldquoVery weird and over the top with the secrecy.Since his sighting, an organisation called the British Earth and Aerial Mysteries Societyhas said it believes he saw an ldquointerdimensional plasma craft.The craft have also been suggested as a cause for recent disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.A spokesperson for Wick John OrsquoGroats Airport confirmed that it was closed during the period the object was sighted, and there are also no reports of the emergency services operating in the air at that time.Charliersquos video can be seen at https:youtu.be xdHBiqtkWhat do you think he saw  Email d.scott@nosnwith your suggestions.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Upgrade should just be the start
story: THE pound. million upgrade of the north section of the Berriedale Braes should be the trigger to improve the rest of that part of the A, according to Caithness councillor Raymond Bremner.He made the plea after Transport Scotland confirmed the contract to upgrade the notorious north hairpin bend has been awarded to Dingwall-based engineering company R J McLeod Ltd. Work is due to start this year, be completed by spring  and create  jobs during the construction phase.Councillor Bremner, who represents Wick and East Caithness on Highland Council, said: "While Im keen to see an improvement to the north brae, I still believe we cant take our focus off the south brae. We have two major long-term concerns to focus on here ndash the gradient of the brae and the fact that we are still witnessing serious accidents on the bottom hairpin bend even where there is an escape bed."These accidents are a risk to le, causing road closures and impacting in all sorts of ways on our local community and economy. Improvements to the north brae are very welcome and I hope that it is the start of a bigger vision to improve the entire Berriedale Braes."We can expect the standard lead-in period of about three months and for discussions to be held with the contractor on how they propose to physically approach the works and discussions with statutory bodies like the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds among others."He said that archaeological investigatory works have been completed.The award of the contract was also welcomed by Trudy Morris, chief executive of Caithness Chamber of Commerce.She said: "We are delighted to see that after many years of dedicated campaigning by the chamber, Caithness Transport Forum and other local organisations, this project is finally moving ahead. For too long, the Berriedale Braes has acted as a pinch point for travellers on the A north of Inverness, disrupting business and jeopardising investment in the region."It has been good to see other work on A improvements and repairs going to local companies in recent years, and we hope the principal contractor will engage closely with our highly skilled local supply chain as these works progress."Ms Morris added: "Now that the contract has been formally awarded, we hope to see clarication on exact start dates and expectedof works very soon. We would urge the Scottish Government to uphold its previous promise to start works within this financial year so that the north Highlands can start to see the benefit of this upgrade as soon as possible."A Transport Scotland spokesman said: "R J McLeod Ltd has been awarded the construction contract as part of the pound. million project to deliver improvements to the road alignment and the existing tight hairpin bend on the A."Michael Matheson, cabinet secretary for transport, hailed it as a positive development for the area. "It will enhance the skills development of the Scottish construction industry, with approximately  jobs expected to be supported in the region during construction."Related articles:Four in running for Berriedale Braes contractSilence on A schemeTuesday  Feb  : PM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: airports chairwoman is appointed
story: IT HAS been announced by Cabinet Secretary for Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity, Michael Matheson MSP, that Lorna Jack had been appointed as chairwoman of the Board of Highlands and Islands Airports Limited , operators of several airports, including Kirkwall Airport.Ms Jack is a chartered accountant and a graduate of Aberdeen University. She joined the Board of Highlands and Islands Airports Limited as a non-executive director in March  and chaired its Audit Committee for over three years, until she was invited to take on the interim chair role in October .Ms Jack remains the chief executive of the Law Society of Scotland and is an independent member of the Court of University of Aberdeen and a member of its Governance and Nominations Committee. She is also a trustee and treasurer of the McConnell International Foundation.The appointment is regulated by the Commissioner for Ethical Standards in Public Le in Scotland.• Highlands and Islands Airports Limitedis a public body wholly owned by Scottish Ministers. title: christmas tree collection reminder
story: Orkney Islands Council is reminding folk that their Christmas tree collection service for households on the Orkney mainland, within mph areas only, will get underway from Monday next week.The limited collection for real trees will be carried between Monday and the following Friday, February .The intention is that trees collected will be recycled at the council’s Bossack waste facility, along with other garden waste left at recycling centres around Orkney, to produce a fine soil conditioner.Therefore anyone using the tree collection service is urged to take extra care that all tinsel and decorations are removed from their trees.The soil conditioner can be picked up free of charge, subject to availability, from the Council’s Household Waste and Recycling Centres at Bossack in Tankerness, and Hatston, in Kirkwall.Collections fall on normal refuse recycling collection days and will take place as follows:Area  — Kirkwall : Monday February Area  — East Holm, Deerness, Tankerness and Toab: Monday February Area  — Stromness : Monday February Area  — Kirkwall : Tuesday February Area  — Kirkwall , Holm and Burray : Tuesday February Area  — Stromnessand Stenness : February Area  — Orphir and Stenness : Friday February Householders who wish to make use of the collection should ensure their Christmas trees are out at the normal collection point by am to guarantee pickup.Householders outwith the mph limits can visit their local Household Waste Recycling Centres at Hatston, Garson, Bossack, Cursiter Quarry, St Margaret’s Hope and Dounby during normal opening hours, where trees can be placed in the #green waste# skips.Opening hours are available on the council#s website, on the Civic Amenity Site page.Trees can also be trimmed, cut up and placed into the kerbside grey bins for the waste collection — as long as the lid can still close on the bin. However, please noteusing this method they cannot be used as soil conditioner and will be shipped along with other waste collected.You can check which area your household falls into on the Your Household Collection — Mainland page of this website.For any enquiries, call the council’s Customer Service team on .copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.From time to time we offer user surveys and questionnaires to provide you with interesting insights, helpful tools, or to understand our user base more accurately. These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the ality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.Third Party CookiesIn some special cases we also use cookies provided by trusted third parties. story: Offers over £,ADVERTORIAL: Westermill is an eye-catching period property located close to the centre of Kirkwall. The property is detached and comprises a large entrance hallway,  spacious bedrooms, one with ensuite, living room, dining room, kitchen, shower room, utility room and downstairs toilet. The property benefits from a large enclosed mature garden to the rear of the property and there are also a driveway and shed to the side of the house.The property has oil-fired central heating, together with a fireplace in the dining room and a Morso stove in the sitting room. There are also fireplaces in two of the bedrooms. Many of the original features have been retained in the property. Viewing is highly recommended to appreciate the true character of Westermill.The property is ideally located on a quiet road close to both the Papdale Primary and Kirkwall Grammar School and it is only a few minutes walk down to the centre of town. To the front of the property is the picturesque Willowburn, as well as additional parking.The living room has a hardwood floor, picture rail and cornice, as does the dining room. There is an archway leading from the dining room to the modern fitted kitchen with  ring hob, double oven, cooker hood, fridge and dishwasher.The ground floor also houses the utility room with plumbing for a washing machine and space for tumble dryer and fridge  freezer. There is a small toilet off the utility room. One of the bedrooms is situated on the ground floor, but could be used as a living room or office space.In the centre of the property is a beautul staircase leading up to a large stained glass feature window and then on to the landing. Off the landing there are a further three double bedrooms, one of which has an en-suite shower room. The main shower room is also located on the first floor of the property.There is a large loft space which is partially floored and could potentially be converted into a further one or two rooms, with ample space on the landing for a staircase.There is a walled garden to the front of the property, bordered with bushes and shrubs. title: german company revealed as third bidder for northern isles ferry tender
story: INTERNATIONAL ferry company FRS Group have been revealed as the third bidder for the Northern Isles ferry service.The company, headquartered in Flensburg, Germany, confirmed the news this week.#FRS follows the tender process. But please understand that we will not disclose any further information on this tender at this time.#It was last month that the Scottish Government stated that an invitation to tender for the next contract to run the Northern Isles ferry services had been issued to three bidders.The names of the companies involved were not released by the government, however Serco NorthLink and Calmac did confirm their involvement.When asked last month, previous bidder Streamline confirmed that it was not one of the bidders on this occasion, leading to speculation over the final company involved.Submission of final tenders is scheduled for March, with a view to awarding the contract in July, said the Scottish Government. The contract is estimated to be worth £m, and will run for eight years.FRS Group runs ferry services throughout many areas of the world, including Europe, North Africa, the Middle East and North America.The organisation is also involved in maritime consultancy and offshore logistics.According to the company, FRS has grown from a regional passenger ferry operator into an internationally active group with  vessels and more than , employees from more than a dozen countries all over the world.FRS annually carries . million passengers and . million vehicles on its numerous national and international shipping lines.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: survey project sheds new light on hms royal oak
story: A VOLUNTEER e team has been granted permission to extensively survey the official wargrave of HMS Royal Oak in Scapa Flow.New D photogrammetry techniques are being used and still photography and videography will allow the team to capture and share the spirit of the site.In the early hours of October , , U’s commander Günther Prien guided her silently into Scapa Flow, and launched a torpedo attack, In just a few minutes, Royal Oak was gone.  sailors perished, including over  boy seamen.Ahead of the th anniversary of her loss later this year, a team of volunteer civilian ers has been granted permission to e the wreck by the secretary of state for defence.This is part of a collaboration with the Royal Oak Association and the Royal Navy to document the last resting place of the men who lost their lives, so their passing can be remembered and preserved for future generations.The project aims to ensure that HMS Royal Oak is not forgotten, by sharing imagery with relatives of those lost, as well as the wider public.The survey team is using state-of-the-art underwater imagery techniques, in order to produce high-quality photography and video. In addition, D photogrammetry is taking place so that digital D models of the wreck can be produced. By using these techniques, in essence, the team is able to digitally bring HMS Royal Oak to the surface.Survey organiser and licence-holder Emily Turton said: “The wreck of HMS Royal Oak is the final resting place of  men and boys. As the most intact underwater dreadnought-era battleship, she has an architectural grandeur befitting of any national memorial. However, at the smaller end of the scale, artefacts pertaining to everyday le on board are scattered around the site, bringing home the human story of those lost. The site is peaceful, yet vibrant, and supports a thriving marine eco-system. It is both an honour and a privilege to get to know the site.”Full details and further pictures in The Orcadian this week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: newsUPDATE: Kirkwall town centre roadworksFebruary ,  at : am vw, px"  Work is set to continue next week on street improvements in Kirkwall#s town centre.There will be further repaving on the area around the TSB bank, on the junction between Castle Street and Broad Street, with a one-way system remaining in place.Orkney Islands Council has said once this initial stage is completed, work will then move to the entrance to Albert Street, meaning the street will be closed to traffic from Laing Street. It#s anticipated this work will start on February  and could take four weeks to complete.The current one-way system means drivers can turn into Castle Street from Junction Road and on into Broad Street but vehicles do not have access from Palace Road into Broad Street.A signed ersion via Clay Loan is in place. In addition, vehicles cannot turn into Castle Street from Albert Street – but can drive on into Broad Street.The works are part of the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiative’sPlaces and Spaces project, which will see improvements to the area at the bottom of the Strynd, the creation of a new path to the War Memorial at St Magnus and improvements at the head of Victoria Street.The council has said the works at the top of Castle Street will see new paving and road surfacing laid, and the road surface raised to pavement level. This initial phase of the project is due for completion early May after which works will be suspended for the main summer season.Work at the entrance to Victoria Street is set to begin in the autumn, with a suspension planned, in December for Christmas shopping season.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: views sought on cursiter quarry expansion plans
story: Orkney Islands Council is providing a further opportunity for the public to view and comment on plans to expand Cursiter Quarry in Firth.The Council is due to submit a planning application for the long-term development of Cursiter Quarry in Firth this Spring.As part of a -phased expansion plan designed to secure additional reserves the quarry could increase in size over the next three decades expanding into neighbouring fields. The planning application also covers landscaping and future restoration of the site.The application process is being handled by consultants AECOM.The council-owned quarry currently supplies stone and aggregate materials for Council roads and building projects as well as the local construction industry.  It extracts Devonian Flagstone which is highly suited to a range of crushed aggregate products, in particular as roadstone and aggregates, used for producing asphalt for road construction and maintenance, with the quarry being the only active producer of asphalt in Orkney.The activity at the quarry generates an income for the Council which is reinvested to provide and protect some of the vital services we provide in Orkney.The current quarry area is heading towards the end of its use and an expansion would safeguard supply of materials. Current output ranges between , and , tonnes of rock per year andapproved, the ha expansion will release approximately  million tonnes of additional resources, sufficient for another  years of production.Full details are available on the Council website at http:www.orkney.gov.uk Council C long-term-development-of-cursiter-quarry-in-firth.htmPersons wishing to provide comments on the proposed development can do so by writing to AECOM at fraser.blackwood@aecom or by post to Fraser Blackwood, APEX ,  Haymarket Terrace, Edinburgh, EH HD by  February .OIC says that, at this stage, comments made to Aecom are for the purposes of assisting with the scheme design and EIA process and as such are not representations to the Planning Authority. title: Black Isle cafes Brexit talk ban raises cash for worthy cause
story: The tongue-in-cheek bid to banish the Brexit blues at Rosemarkie Beach Cafeacute over the festive season saw customers warned theyrsquod face a pound finethey so much as mentioned a word seldom out of the headlines lately.Philip Eley, the long-standing cafeacute manager, explained. ldquoItrsquos just grim. People are so depressed. Folk come to the beach to get away from all those headlines about what the idiots in Westminster are up to, but it only takes one person to mention the B-word to ruin everyone rsquos bacon roll.Customers warmed to the idea and willingly dropped contributions in the bucket during visits to the Black Isle beauty spot.Mr Eleyrsquos partner, Verity Walker, made good on a promise to donate takings from the offbeat bucket collection to the Maggiersquos Highlands cancer care centre at Raigmore Hospital. It was gratefully accepted by fundraising manager David Walker, who is no relation. Ms Walker said: ldquoWe finally got the donations bucket and collecting can to the Maggiersquos Centre at Raigmore ndash they were quite heavy as we kept them on the counter a bit longer and you just kept on giving!ldquoMaggiersquos has helped a number of cafeacute customers and staff. They exist to support those who are affected by cancer, but that includes the families of those diagnosed. If you have never been in, please go and visit, itrsquos a lovely calm space amid the hustle and bustle of Raigmore.Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Black Isle festival issues tongue in cheek invite to ex Oasis star
story: The announcement last week that Noel Gallagher and his High Flying Birds will take to the stage in Inverness on June  was greeted with delight by fans of the multimillion-selling star who shot to fame as the creative force behind Oasis.Less thrilled about the timing of the Bught Park gig, organised by Live in the City and boasting support from Razorlight and Neon Waltz, were the organisers of the Black Isle-based Woodzstock, scheduled to take place on the same date in an outdoor adventure park near Tore, just a few miles from Gallaghers headline-grabbing gig.Woodzstock organisers Charlotte and Dave Elliott admit they were rocked ndash and not in a good way ndash when they learned of the clash. Within hours they rallied with a defiant show must go on plan ndash to invite Gallagher to perform at their intimate venue ahead of his own show in the Highland capital.Charlotte said: "Were excited that big names like Noel Gallaghers High Flying Birds are coming to the Highlands andwe werent holding our festival on the same day we would have loved to see them play. We didnt want to miss him so were inviting Noel to come along and play a few tunes at Woodzstock before his gig in Inverness."She added: "We know it a long shot! Were asking the public to help us by posting online sharing the hashtag #GetNoeltoWoodz"Now entering its third year, Woodzstock has grown year on year with more bands, festival-goers and local businesses, including food producers, artists and performers, sound engineers and local charities, benefiting.Charlotte said: "This year promises to the best Woodzstock yet, we have some fantastic bands already booked, amazing locally sourced food and drink and activities running for the kids. An appearance from Noel would be amazing. We hope our invitation reaches him and he knows our stage will be ready for him".No one from Live in the City was available for comment on the fixture clash. Mr Gallagher could not be reached for comment.Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Businesses gearing up for new adventure festival in Inverness
story: Highland Adventure Fest is expected to take place in Inverness Leisure Centre on Sunday, March .And the event is expected to feature presentations and entertainment from outdoor enthusiasts, as well as demonstrations and live music.The event is being advertised to those who have an interest in outdoor activities such as mountain biking, hiking, and kayaking among others.Festival-goers will be able to try out kit, buy new clothing and equipment, book activities and meet new people with similar interests while enjoying presentations and entertainment on the main stage.The mini festival is being planned by Inverness-based event organisers PLANIT Scotland and will be sponsored by the Glenmore Lodge in Aviemore.Katie Masheter, from PLANIT Scotland, said: ldquoWe are organising the event because the Highlands are quite often seen as a bit of an adventure playground.Miss Masheter went on to say that although they are expecting mostly local people at the event they welcome tourists to come along also, she said: ldquoVisitScotlandrsquos recent tourism conference was placing emphasis on getting the country set-up for an influx of tourists looking for adventure, so what we thought would be great is to pull together an event which brings everyone under one roof.The event is open to all.Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Check your cold weather payment eligibility says Ross MP as temperature plummets
story: Local MP Ian Blackford sayspeople in the Ross, Skye and Lochaber constituency he serves should check eligibility with their nearest Job Centre Plus.This follows an alert of a triggering of the payment for postcode areas IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, between the period    to   .Cold weather payments are made from the Social Fund to certain recipients of Income Support, income-based Jobseekerrsquos Allowance, income-related Employment and Support Allowance, Universal Credit or Pension Credit during periods of very cold weather.To ldquotrigger the payments, the average temperature at a specied weather station must be recorded as, or forecast to be, degC or below for seven consecutive days.The scheme runs from November  to March  each year.The payment is a fixed amount for each week of cold weather. For many years this was set at pound. a week but the LabourGovernment increased the rate to pound a week as a temporary measure for winters - and -. In , the Coalition Government made the pound rate permanent.Payments should be made automatically to those entitled to them there should be no need to make a claim.However concerns have previously been raised that payments can be missed and Mr Blackford believes it is important that people, who believe that they may be eligible follow this through, particularly as the cold weather bites.He said: ldquoWe have been experiencing quite a prolonged period of cold and wet weather in the Highlands and Islands. It is hugely important that anyone eligible for a cold weather payment receives it. It can really make a dference to a vulnerable person or family who is experiencing high heating costs.ldquoThese payments should be made to eligible iniduals automatically, however, in my experience that is not always the case. I would urge anyone who believes that they may be due a payment to contact their nearest Job Centre Plus and get what they are owed.Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Ex pat never forgot native Black Isle
story: TRIBUTES have been paid to a former Black Isle man who died at home after battling an illness for several years.Although he moved to Hannibal in Missouri in the s, Kenneth Macdonald, who was born in Fortrose in , retained a lasting interest in his home town, following events from afar through the hugely popular Fortrose and Rosemarkie Past and Present Facebook page.Mr Macdonald shared with that grouprsquos leading light, John Mackenzie, a great interest in motor sports and owned two lovely classic cars, a Triumph TR and a Corvette.Mr Mackenzie said he had decided to use the page to share news of the former Fortrose manrsquos death with others who might have known him. His father ran the family businesses, a coal merchant and a plasterers business in Fortrose.Mr Mackenzie said: ldquoKen ed to his home following a y stay in hospital.ldquoHe was delighted to sit in his own home and in his favourite chair and even smoked a cigarette. Irsquom sure that many of you will join me in offering our sincere condolences to his two daughters Mhairi and Katie and to their families.Mr Macdonaldrsquos late we, Susan, passed away in .During his early years in Fortrose, his budding talents emerged. He studied civil engineering at Edinburgh University and won a bursary to further his studies in the United States at Washington University in St Louis. It was in the States he met his we Susan whom he married in .Mr Macdonald also spent time during a distinguished engineering career in Benbecula during a period when the couple had moved to Edinburgh. There he was working with a contractor who in turn worked for the Ministry of Defence.His elder daughter Mhairi was born during the time they lived in Benbecula.After Benbecula the family moved to Hannibal where Mr Macdonald continued to work as an engineer.He was resident engineer with the Missouridepartment of transportationoverseeing the building of the Mark Twain Memorial Bridge across the Mississippi in the late s.Mr Macdonald continued toto Fortrose when possible but failing health over the past number of years meant that it was no longer possible.His passion for the place he grew up during his formative years was kindled by the local photographs posted on a regular basis on the Facebook page, ranging from present-day scenes to some more nostalgic images.He was also a member of the Hannibal Loafers car club.Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Highland MPs scathing after Prime Minister vows to reopen Brexit backstop negotiations
story: The - vote victory came after Speaker John Bercow selected seven amendments that iously sought to extend the date of departure, make a lsquono-dealrsquo impossible, place the Brexit process in the hands of parliament, and find an alternative to the Northern Ireland back-stop.All were defeated except the Brady Amendment ndash seeking a renegotiated backstop - and a non-binding motion calling for an economically damaging lsquono-dealrsquo to be ruled out.But Theresa May looks set to face a struggle reopening the Withdrawl Agreement negotiated with the EU after European Council president, Donald Tusk, immediately shot down the proposals, stating: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford, who is also MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber, had earlier submitted an amendment noting how the Scottish and Welsh assemblies voted against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, calling for an extension of article  ndash which would delay the UKrsquos EU departure - and for no deal to be removed as an option. It was defeated by  votes to .He warned that the development means Number  has brought the country closer to a no-deal Brexit and undermined the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland.ldquoBy throwing her weight behind an impossible demand from the hard Brexit wing of the Conservative Party the Prime Minister today demonstrated beyond doubt she is now prepared to take Scotland and the UK over the Brexit clf-edge.ldquoTheresa May could have worked across parties to protect jobs and living standards but she chose to side with the Brexit extremists in her own party.ldquoOnce again Scotland has been silenced, sidelined and shafted by Westminster, and we are paying a heavy price for a chaotic Tory government that Scotland did not vote for. And today the Tories ripped apart the Good Friday agreement, an international treaty the UK had signed up to."His SNP colleague Drew Hendry, who represents Inverness,Nairn,Badenoch and Strathspey, added: ldquoWith her Brexit deal in tatters after its record-breaking defeat in the House of Commons, Theresa Mays focus remains on appeasing her Tory colleagues, rather than on delivering a plan to protect jobs and the economy.ldquoShe knows this fudge on the Irish backstop cannot be delivered in any meaningful way, yet she continues to waste what valuable time is left. It is little wonder the EU  are so bemused by her behaviour.ldquoAs ever, it is the public who will pay the price for this shambles. The Prime Minister has made no attempt to recognise the views of the Scottish electorate, and the damage Brexit will cause to the Scottish economy.ldquoLabour has shown they are also not to be trusted, leaving us facing the prospect of being hauled out of the EU and made to endure all the damage that brings. It is clear Westminster is not working for Scotland and its time to take ownership of our own future.The Liberal Democrats voted in favour of the Labour MP Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment which was defeated by  votes to . It sought more to allow parliament more time to figure out how to break the deadlock.When this failed Liberal Democrat MP Jamie Stone, who represents Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross,argued for a Peoplersquos Vote because crashing out with no-deal would, he said, be a disaster for those in the far north.ldquoJobs, infrastructure, health care in my constituency all rely on EU citizens to fill vital roles and on EU funding," he explained.ldquoMPs who voted in favour of Bradyrsquos amendment were knowingly voting for a no deal Brexit. The EU had made it very clear to all involved that they would not reopen negotiations. These MPs are running after a fantasy and itrsquos British people who will pay the price.ldquoAll Theresa May has done is kick the can down the road and run the clock down even further. She is gambling with time we just donrsquot have.Mr Stone also sought to underline the importance of the non-binding Spelman amendment which stated the UK will not leave the EU without a deal.ldquoLabour MPs who sat on their hands have once again facilitated Theresa May and the European Research Groupin their pursuit of a no deal Brexit.ldquoA win for amendment ldquoI means the government has once again been told that there is no majority in the house for a no deal Brexit. The PM needs to take no deal off the table - as she should have done months ago - and recognise that people are not in favour of a hard Brexit which will damage our country.Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: New homes planned for Dingwall
story: DINGWALL moved a step closer to getting  new homes after the Ross and Cromarty area committee agreed an infrastructure investment ldquounlocking the possibility of the development.But councillors were at odds over the plans with some considering them a sop in lieu of the  homes earmarked for the town since  while others said it was a ldquopositive move in a high pressure area for housing demand.The original plan was based on the delivery of the Kinnairdie Link Roadproject ndash expected to unleash millions in inward investment. It was due to start its final phase of construction this year but it was axed from the councilrsquos capital programme in last yearrsquos budget.Then in March, funding for transport improvements in Dingwall was found to enable some housing development to take place prior to the commencement of the KLR.A transport study and modelling work considered the impact of ious levels of development in the town and improvements will include work at the Bridgend Avenue Junction and Docharty Road Junction as well as traffic signal works at Mart Road Junction. Proposals for walking and cycling improvements and traffic management measures will also be brought forward to enhance active travel facilities in the town.Dingwall and Seaforth councillor Graham Mackenzie said: ldquoIt would be tempting to see it as a good news story for Dingwall. That is not the case. Had we been given what we were promised in an earlier iteration of the capital plan we could be releasing up to  houses for development instead of around ."Instead the KLR was taken out of the capital plan even though the first phase of the project had already started. If Dingwall is to grow and provide the range of housing which is required, the KLR must be moved up the list of priorities. This project needs to be reinstated.Fellow ward councillor Angela Maclean insisted the deal was good news. She said: ldquoWe as councillors have a leadership role and it is up to us to be helping our communities to move forward and this report has examples of when officers have looked for solutions to get round some of the fact that we donrsquot have all the money we would like."Whether it is through the infrastructure road plans or capital fund we are going to try and move forward with these houses in Dingwall, because Dingwall is a pressurised area ndash this is a positive move because we donrsquot have enough houses in Dingwall.Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Old office goes back on market in Dingwall
story: The former assessorrsquos office in Ferry Road, which adjoins the old Sherf Court, dates back to .A category B listed commercial property it was on the market a year ago and it was thought a buyer had been found. But the sale fell through and the property is again up for sale with offers over pound, invited.Originally built as a police station, the property has a colourful history with its location next to the courthouse.The sherf court was closed by the Scottish Court Service in January  as part of a cost-cutting and restructuring scheme.The following year the property was sold and converted into a private dwelling. The former police station been used for many years by Highland Council as offices for the assessor.The assessor is responsible for assigning a value to properties for tax purposes.Because it was a commercial property it is not necessary to provide a survey of the building to potential buyers.It is in a mix of modern and traditional residential properties close to the town centre on Ferry Road.Of stone and slate construction it comprises three rooms on the ground floor and four rooms on the first floor.A council spokesman said the property requires extensive work, but it has its own entrance and parking to the front of the property.The closing date set for offers is March , .Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Ross nurses lead the way
story: Chrissie Laneand Lucy Heycockentered the gruelling Strathpeffer -hour mountain bike challenge with the aim of encouraging some of their patients and colleagues to embrace new challenges and experiences.The annual event near Strathpeffer sees riders tackle freezing temperatures,  hours of darkness and mile upon mile of frozen forest tracks.The dynamic duo were delighted with a podium finish. Macmillan cancer consultant nurse Chrissie, from Culbokie, said: ldquoWe work every day with amazing people living with cancer and are trying to support them to be active outdoors which has huge proven benefits to their health and recovery.ldquoMaking small or big changes to the amount of moving your body does throughout the day have immense benefits for people living with cancer.Theyrsquore promoting everything from short walks and cycle rides to hillwalking.Chrissie added: ldquoThe reason why we took part in the event was to try to be role models for older woman to just give experiences a try. All it needs is a gritty frame of mind and a sense of humour and fun when situations are not so pleasant.Chrissie and advanced nurse colleague Lucy, from Muir of Ord, were delighted with a podium finish, coming in an extremely credible third in the competitionrsquos female pairs category.Both Chrissie and Lucy hope that their success shows that you can take up and enjoy exercise, even doing an event like the challenging Strathpuffer, at any age.Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Tain hub and Picture House project progress to come under spotlight
story: Tain and District Development Trusthas already been successful in raising well over pound, towards its projects and secured three employed positions for the local area.On Thursday, February the group is staging a community consultation in the towns Duthac Centre at pm.TDDTs Sarah Mackenzie said: "Weve worked hard to gain a closer relationship with local businesses and groups within Tain and district in order to increase our social and economic impact to the local area making us more attractive to potential funders and investors."To date we have bid and successfully received funding for ourselves and partner projects from FirstPort, Highlands and Islands Enterprise, SSE Beatrice Wind Farm, Beinn Tharsuinn Wind farm Trust and Highland Council."With these funds we are now in a position to employ a community fund manager, business development manager and an administrator to help take our projects to the next level and increase our community-wide benefit. We hope to have these positions filled by early spring."The funds will also allowTDDT to fit out its new community enterprise hub on Stafford Street inTain.Said Ms Mackenzie: "The hub will be the cornerstone to all of our projects as well as providing a space that caters to the wider community offering conferencing facilities, meeting rooms, hot desking andpop-up phops. We hope to be open for business in March this year."Highlands and Islands Enterpriseis providing funding support towards the cost of developing the hub and recruiting a manager.Stewart Wardlaw, HIE Development Manager, Inner Moray Firth area, said: "The Hub will provide valuable business services locally, for commercial and social enterprises."It will also help facilitate the use of business premises within the local community and in a town centre location. This will help make the Tain district a more attractive option for businesses and drive growth locally."We are very pleased to be able to provide support and look forward to seeing the project develop.Through the SSE Beatrice Wind Farm Fund, TDDThas received funds to cover the costs for a full business plan and feasibility study towards the Picture House project.Along with Tain Heritage Trust and Tain and Easter Ross Civic Trust,TDDT hasalready managed to successfully clear the outside of the premises andtidy up inside,allowing the community a rare glimpse of a building through photographs thatmany hold close to their hearts.The Beatrice Partnership Fund said it wasdelighted to support the community withits aspirations to restorethe iconic local building.Tain Heritage Trusts Chairman David Robertson welcomed the support theyve had in recent months from Tain  Easter Ross Civic Trust and from Tain  District Development Trust to help kick-start the Picture House redevelopment.He said: "This help has now secured us funding for a feasibilitystudy from SSE.We welcome the involvement of SSE in what really would be a transformational project for the town."Lets hope this is the start of a fruitful partnership with them to secure the phased restoration of our Royal Burghs much-loved hall. Our town can only prosper when groups work together for the CommonWeal. Thats what we are seeing with the Development Trust. Long may it continue."Tain and Easter Ross Civic Trust says it is proud to be playing a signicant role in the restoration of this building dating from  it is one of the finest works of the Maitland firm of architects who designed so many of the Victorian and Edwardian buildings that form such an important part of Tains heritage.Hamish Mackenzie of the Trust said: "It played a major role in the le of Tain, first as a public hall and then from  s as a cinema and we hope to see it resuming to its former glory in the st century."The community consultation on Thursday in the Duthac Centre at pm will give people a chance to see the development made so far as well as having their say on future developments.Member votes will required to make amendments to our constitution in order to progress the Picture House Project and to secure larger funds and investments.Tuesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies.
